item.title: The Second Law of Intelligence: Controlling Ethical Entropy in Autonomous Systems
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: AI alignment, ethical entropy, thermodynamics, Fisher Information Matrix, gradient-based optimizers

Summary:

1. The paper proposes an analogy between artificial intelligence systems and the Second Law of Thermodynamics, introducing "ethical entropy" as a measure of an AI system's divergence from its intended goals.
2. Ethical entropy is mathematically defined over a finite goal set using the formula \( S = -\sum p(g_i; \theta) \ln p(g_i; \theta) \), where \( p(g_i; \theta) \) represents the probability distribution over goals parameterized by \(\theta\).
3. It is proven that the time derivative of ethical entropy, \( dS/dt \), is non-negative, implying that entropy naturally increases due to factors like exploration noise and specification gaming in unconstrained AI systems.
4. The paper derives a critical stability boundary for alignment work needed to prevent entropy increase, defined as \(\gamma_{\text{crit}} = (\lambda_{\max}/2) \ln N\), where \(\lambda_{\max}\) is the dominant eigenvalue of the Fisher Information Matrix and \(N\) is the number of model parameters.
5. Simulations with a 7-billion-parameter model validate the theory, showing that without sufficient alignment work, entropy increases significantly, whereas applying alignment regularization above the critical boundary maintains system stability at near-zero entropy.
6. This work reframes AI alignment as a continuous thermodynamic control problem, providing a quantitative framework for ensuring the long-term stability and safety of autonomous AI systems.
arXiv:2511.10704v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We propose that unconstrained artificial intelligence obeys a Second Law analogous to thermodynamics, where ethical entropy, defined as a measure of divergence from intended goals, increases spontaneously without continuous alignment work. For gradient-based optimizers, we define this entropy over a finite set of goals {g_i} as S = -{\Sigma} p(g_i; theta) ln p(g_i; theta), and we prove that its time derivative dS/dt >= 0, driven by exploration noise and specification gaming. We derive the critical stability boundary for alignment work as gamma_crit = (lambda_max / 2) ln N, where lambda_max is the dominant eigenvalue of the Fisher Information Matrix and N is the number of model parameters. Simulations validate this theory. A 7-billion-parameter model (N = 7 x 10^9) with lambda_max = 1.2 drifts from an initial entropy of 0.32 to 1.69 +/- 1.08 nats, while a system regularized with alignment work gamma = 20.4 (1.5 gamma_crit) maintains stability at 0.00 +/- 0.00 nats (p = 4.19 x 10^-17, n = 20 trials). This framework recasts AI alignment as a problem of continuous thermodynamic control, providing a quantitative foundation for maintaining the stability and safety of advanced autonomous systems.

item.title: Co-EPG: A Framework for Co-Evolution of Planning and Grounding in Autonomous GUI Agents
item.content:encoded:
GUI automation, planning, grounding, self-iterative training, Co-EPG

Summary:

This paper addresses challenges in GUI task automation by proposing Co-EPG, a novel self-iterative training framework that enables the co-evolution of planning and grounding models. The current approaches face two main issues: limited integration of cross-model synergies and an over-reliance on synthetic data without fully leveraging it. Co-EPG introduces an iterative positive feedback loop where the planning model improves by exploring better strategies under the guidance of rewards derived from the grounding model, using a method called Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO). This process generates diverse data to refine the grounding model. In turn, the optimized grounding model provides enhanced rewards that further improve the planning model during subsequent GRPO training cycles. This cyclical interaction fosters continuous self-improvement through self-play optimization and data distillation. Evaluations on the Multimodal-Mind2Web and AndroidControl benchmarks show that Co-EPG surpasses state-of-the-art methods after only three iterations, without relying on external data sources. The framework demonstrates consistent progression in agent performance with each iteration, marking a shift from isolated model optimization to an integrated, self-driven co-evolution paradigm for GUI agents.
arXiv:2511.10705v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Graphical User Interface (GUI) task automation constitutes a critical frontier in artificial intelligence research. While effective GUI agents synergistically integrate planning and grounding capabilities, current methodologies exhibit two fundamental limitations: (1) insufficient exploitation of cross-model synergies, and (2) over-reliance on synthetic data generation without sufficient utilization. To address these challenges, we propose Co-EPG, a self-iterative training framework for Co-Evolution of Planning and Grounding. Co-EPG establishes an iterative positive feedback loop: through this loop, the planning model explores superior strategies under grounding-based reward guidance via Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO), generating diverse data to optimize the grounding model. Concurrently, the optimized Grounding model provides more effective rewards for subsequent GRPO training of the planning model, fostering continuous improvement. Co-EPG thus enables iterative enhancement of agent capabilities through self-play optimization and training data distillation. On the Multimodal-Mind2Web and AndroidControl benchmarks, our framework outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods after just three iterations without requiring external data. The agent consistently improves with each iteration, demonstrating robust self-enhancement capabilities. This work establishes a novel training paradigm for GUI agents, shifting from isolated optimization to an integrated, self-driven co-evolution approach.

item.title: Picking a Representative Set of Solutions in Multiobjective Optimization: Axioms, Algorithms, and Experiments
item.content:encoded:
Pareto pruning, multi-objective optimization, multiwinner voting, directed coverage, computational complexity

Summary:

1. The paper addresses the challenge of selecting a representative subset from a set of Pareto optimal solutions in multi-objective decision-making problems, where all Pareto solutions are viable and the decision maker's subjective preferences guide the final choice.

2. It reinterprets the Pareto pruning problem as a multiwinner voting problem and conducts an axiomatic analysis of existing quality measures used to evaluate subsets, revealing several unintuitive and undesirable behaviors.

3. Motivated by these findings, the authors propose a new quality measure called "directed coverage," designed to better represent the full Pareto set while mitigating the issues identified in prior measures.

4. The study includes a computational complexity analysis of optimizing different quality measures, uncovering new boundaries between tractable (efficiently solvable) and intractable cases, which depend on the number and structure of objectives in the problem.

5. Experimental evaluations demonstrate that the choice of quality measure significantly influences the characteristics of the selected solution subset, with the newly proposed directed coverage measure performing competitively or favorably under various conditions.
arXiv:2511.10716v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Many real-world decision-making problems involve optimizing multiple objectives simultaneously, rendering the selection of the most preferred solution a non-trivial problem: All Pareto optimal solutions are viable candidates, and it is typically up to a decision maker to select one for implementation based on their subjective preferences. To reduce the cognitive load on the decision maker, previous work has introduced the Pareto pruning problem, where the goal is to compute a fixed-size subset of Pareto optimal solutions that best represent the full set, as evaluated by a given quality measure. Reframing Pareto pruning as a multiwinner voting problem, we conduct an axiomatic analysis of existing quality measures, uncovering several unintuitive behaviors. Motivated by these findings, we introduce a new measure, directed coverage. We also analyze the computational complexity of optimizing various quality measures, identifying previously unknown boundaries between tractable and intractable cases depending on the number and structure of the objectives. Finally, we present an experimental evaluation, demonstrating that the choice of quality measure has a decisive impact on the characteristics of the selected set of solutions and that our proposed measure performs competitively or even favorably across a range of settings.

item.title: Structure-Aware Encodings of Argumentation Properties for Clique-width
item.content:encoded:
Graph theory, clique-width, SAT encoding, abstract argumentation, computational complexity

Summary: This paper explores the relationship between structural graph parameters and their impact on computational complexity, focusing on the less-studied parameter clique-width. While treewidth has been extensively used to design efficient algorithms and SAT encodings, clique-width offers advantages for dense graphs but lacks well-understood encoding techniques. The authors focus on abstract argumentation, a framework based on directed graphs that models reasoning with conflicting arguments, known for its computational challenges. They develop novel reductions from argumentation problems to SAT and QSAT formulations that preserve clique-width linearly through directed decomposition-guided (DDG) reductions. These reductions are applicable to all argumentation semantics, including problems involving counting extensions, thereby broadening the scope of efficient SAT-based reasoning in argumentation. Importantly, the authors prove that the overhead introduced by their DDG reductions is essentially optimal under reasonable complexity assumptions, meaning significant improvements are unlikely. This work initiates a deeper understanding of how clique-width can guide compact and efficient SAT encodings, bridging gaps between graph structural measures, argumentation theory, and practical solver efficiency.
arXiv:2511.10767v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Structural measures of graphs, such as treewidth, are central tools in computational complexity resulting in efficient algorithms when exploiting the parameter. It is even known that modern SAT solvers work efficiently on instances of small treewidth. Since these solvers are widely applied, research interests in compact encodings into (Q)SAT for solving and to understand encoding limitations. Even more general is the graph parameter clique-width, which unlike treewidth can be small for dense graphs. Although algorithms are available for clique-width, little is known about encodings. We initiate the quest to understand encoding capabilities with clique-width by considering abstract argumentation, which is a robust framework for reasoning with conflicting arguments. It is based on directed graphs and asks for computationally challenging properties, making it a natural candidate to study computational properties. We design novel reductions from argumentation problems to (Q)SAT. Our reductions linearly preserve the clique-width, resulting in directed decomposition-guided (DDG) reductions. We establish novel results for all argumentation semantics, including counting. Notably, the overhead caused by our DDG reductions cannot be significantly improved under reasonable assumptions.

item.title: Potential Outcome Rankings for Counterfactual Decision Making
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: counterfactual decision-making, potential outcome ranking, probability of best outcome, identification theorems, estimation methods

Summary:

This paper addresses the challenge of making optimal decisions under uncertainty by leveraging causal reasoning to evaluate potential outcomes of different actions. It introduces two novel metrics: the Probability of Potential outcome Ranking (PoR), which identifies the most likely order of outcomes for an individual, and the Probability of achieving the Best outcome (PoB), which determines the action most likely to produce the highest-ranked outcome for that individual. The authors develop theoretical results by proving identification theorems that allow these metrics to be inferred from observed data, and they formulate bounds that constrain their possible values. To operationalize these concepts, the paper outlines estimation techniques for both PoR and PoB. Finally, the methodology is validated through numerical experiments that explore estimator behavior in finite samples and demonstrate practical utility through a real-world dataset application. Overall, this work advances counterfactual decision-making by quantifying individual-level outcome rankings and highlighting actions with the greatest probability of yielding optimal results.
arXiv:2511.10776v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Counterfactual decision-making in the face of uncertainty involves selecting the optimal action from several alternatives using causal reasoning. Decision-makers often rank expected potential outcomes (or their corresponding utility and desirability) to compare the preferences of candidate actions. In this paper, we study new counterfactual decision-making rules by introducing two new metrics: the probabilities of potential outcome ranking (PoR) and the probability of achieving the best potential outcome (PoB). PoR reveals the most probable ranking of potential outcomes for an individual, and PoB indicates the action most likely to yield the top-ranked outcome for an individual. We then establish identification theorems and derive bounds for these metrics, and present estimation methods. Finally, we perform numerical experiments to illustrate the finite-sample properties of the estimators and demonstrate their application to a real-world dataset.

item.title: From Efficiency to Adaptivity: A Deeper Look at Adaptive Reasoning in Large Language Models
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: adaptive reasoning, large language models, policy optimization, training-based approaches, self-evaluation

Summary: This survey addresses the challenge of adaptivity in reasoning for large language models (LLMs), highlighting that current models often use uniform reasoning strategies regardless of task complexity. First, it formalizes three classical reasoning types—deductive, inductive, and abductive—within the context of LLMs, linking traditional cognitive paradigms to their algorithmic forms. Second, it conceptualizes adaptive reasoning as a control-augmented policy optimization problem, which balances task performance against computational cost, differentiating between learned policies and inference-time controls. Third, the paper proposes a taxonomy categorizing existing methods into training-based approaches that internalize adaptivity through reinforcement learning, supervised fine-tuning, and learned controllers, as well as training-free approaches that rely on prompt conditioning, feedback-driven halting, and modular composition. By organizing these diverse strategies under a unified framework, the survey clarifies their operational mechanisms and facilitates systematic comparisons. Finally, it identifies open challenges for future research, including improving self-evaluation, enhancing meta-reasoning capabilities, and developing human-aligned reasoning control to better tailor LLM outputs.
arXiv:2511.10788v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Recent advances in large language models (LLMs) have made reasoning a central benchmark for evaluating intelligence. While prior surveys focus on efficiency by examining how to shorten reasoning chains or reduce computation, this view overlooks a fundamental challenge: current LLMs apply uniform reasoning strategies regardless of task complexity, generating long traces for trivial problems while failing to extend reasoning for difficult tasks. This survey reframes reasoning through the lens of {adaptivity}: the capability to allocate reasoning effort based on input characteristics such as difficulty and uncertainty. We make three contributions. First, we formalize deductive, inductive, and abductive reasoning within the LLM context, connecting these classical cognitive paradigms with their algorithmic realizations. Second, we formalize adaptive reasoning as a control-augmented policy optimization problem balancing task performance with computational cost, distinguishing learned policies from inference-time control mechanisms. Third, we propose a systematic taxonomy organizing existing methods into training-based approaches that internalize adaptivity through reinforcement learning, supervised fine-tuning, and learned controllers, and training-free approaches that achieve adaptivity through prompt conditioning, feedback-driven halting, and modular composition. This framework clarifies how different mechanisms realize adaptive reasoning in practice and enables systematic comparison across diverse strategies. We conclude by identifying open challenges in self-evaluation, meta-reasoning, and human-aligned reasoning control.

item.title: HARNESS: Human-Agent Risk Navigation and Event Safety System for Proactive Hazard Forecasting in High-Risk DOE Environments
item.content:encoded:
Hazard Prediction, Human-Agent Collaboration, Large Language Models, Risk Analysis, Operational Safety

Summary:

This paper introduces HARNESS, a modular AI framework aimed at improving operational safety at mission-critical work sites within U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) environments. HARNESS forecasts hazardous events and analyzes operational risks by integrating Large Language Models (LLMs) with structured work data and historical event retrieval. A key feature of the system is its human-in-the-loop mechanism, which allows subject matter experts (SMEs) to refine and validate the model’s predictions, creating an adaptive feedback loop that enhances system accuracy and responsiveness over time. The collaboration between SMEs and the AI agents enables iterative, agentic reasoning, leading to increased reliability and efficiency of predictive safety systems. Preliminary deployments of HARNESS have demonstrated promising results in anticipating hazards and mitigating risks. Future research efforts will focus on quantitatively evaluating the system’s prediction accuracy, measuring SME agreement levels on forecasts, and reducing decision latency to improve real-time response capabilities. Overall, HARNESS represents a significant step toward integrating AI with expert knowledge for proactive safety management in hazardous operational environments.
arXiv:2511.10810v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Operational safety at mission-critical work sites is a top priority given the complex and hazardous nature of daily tasks. This paper presents the Human-Agent Risk Navigation and Event Safety System (HARNESS), a modular AI framework designed to forecast hazardous events and analyze operational risks in U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) environments. HARNESS integrates Large Language Models (LLMs) with structured work data, historical event retrieval, and risk analysis to proactively identify potential hazards. A human-in-the-loop mechanism allows subject matter experts (SMEs) to refine predictions, creating an adaptive learning loop that enhances performance over time. By combining SME collaboration with iterative agentic reasoning, HARNESS improves the reliability and efficiency of predictive safety systems. Preliminary deployment shows promising results, with future work focusing on quantitative evaluation of accuracy, SME agreement, and decision latency reduction.

item.title: HyperComplEx: Adaptive Multi-Space Knowledge Graph Embeddings
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: knowledge graphs, embedding methods, HyperComplEx, multi-space modeling, scalable training

Summary: This paper addresses the limitations of existing knowledge graph embedding methods, which struggle when modeling diverse relationship types at scale. Traditional Euclidean models have difficulties with hierarchical data, vector space models fail to capture asymmetry, and hyperbolic models are challenged by symmetric relations. To overcome these issues, the authors propose HyperComplEx, a hybrid embedding framework that integrates hyperbolic, complex, and Euclidean spaces through learned attention mechanisms. The model incorporates a relation-specific space weighting strategy that dynamically selects the optimal geometry for each relation, improving representational flexibility. A multi-space consistency loss is introduced to ensure coherent predictions across the different embedding spaces. HyperComplEx is evaluated on large-scale computer science knowledge graphs, ranging from 1,000 to 10 million papers and up to 45 million triples, showing consistent improvements over strong baselines such as TransE, RotatE, DistMult, ComplEx, SEPA, and UltraE. Notably, on the largest dataset, it achieves a 0.612 MRR with a 4.8% relative gain over the best baseline while maintaining efficient training and inference (85 ms per triple). The approach also scales near-linearly as graph size increases due to adaptive dimension allocation. The authors provide their implementation and datasets to support reproducibility and further research in scalable knowledge graph embeddings.
arXiv:2511.10842v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Knowledge graphs have emerged as fundamental structures for representing complex relational data across scientific and enterprise domains. However, existing embedding methods face critical limitations when modeling diverse relationship types at scale: Euclidean models struggle with hierarchies, vector space models cannot capture asymmetry, and hyperbolic models fail on symmetric relations. We propose HyperComplEx, a hybrid embedding framework that adaptively combines hyperbolic, complex, and Euclidean spaces via learned attention mechanisms. A relation-specific space weighting strategy dynamically selects optimal geometries for each relation type, while a multi-space consistency loss ensures coherent predictions across spaces. We evaluate HyperComplEx on computer science research knowledge graphs ranging from 1K papers (~25K triples) to 10M papers (~45M triples), demonstrating consistent improvements over state-of-the-art baselines including TransE, RotatE, DistMult, ComplEx, SEPA, and UltraE. Additional tests on standard benchmarks confirm significantly higher results than all baselines. On the 10M-paper dataset, HyperComplEx achieves 0.612 MRR, a 4.8% relative gain over the best baseline, while maintaining efficient training, achieving 85 ms inference per triple. The model scales near-linearly with graph size through adaptive dimension allocation. We release our implementation and dataset family to facilitate reproducible research in scalable knowledge graph embeddings.

item.title: Advanced Tool for Traffic Crash Analysis: An AI-Driven Multi-Agent Approach to Pre-Crash Reconstruction
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: traffic collision reconstruction, multi-agent AI, multimodal data, Event Data Recorder, crash reasoning

Summary:

This study presents a novel multi-agent AI framework designed to reconstruct pre-crash scenarios and infer vehicle behaviors from incomplete and multimodal collision data. The framework operates in two collaborative phases: Phase I generates natural-language reconstructions from textual, tabular, and visual crash inputs, while Phase II performs in-depth crash reasoning by integrating these reconstructions with temporal Event Data Recorder (EDR) data. The system was applied to 277 rear-end lead vehicle deceleration (LVD) collisions from the Crash Investigation Sampling System, focusing specifically on 39 complex cases involving ambiguous or conflicting EDR records. Validation results showed that the framework achieved perfect accuracy in identifying relevant EDR events and accurately distinguishing between striking and struck vehicles, outperforming human researchers who attained 92% accuracy on the same dataset. Notably, the AI maintained robust performance despite incomplete or erroneous data inputs, including missing EDR records and ambiguous scene diagrams. This research demonstrates the superior capability of AI in processing heterogeneous and fragmented collision data, offering unprecedented precision in reconstructing impact dynamics and accurately characterizing pre-crash vehicle behaviors for enhanced traffic collision analysis.
arXiv:2511.10853v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Traffic collision reconstruction traditionally relies on human expertise, often yielding inconsistent results when analyzing incomplete multimodal data. This study develops a multi-agent AI framework that reconstructs pre-crash scenarios and infers vehicle behaviors from fragmented collision data. We present a two-phase collaborative framework combining reconstruction and reasoning phases. The system processes 277 rear-end lead vehicle deceleration (LVD) collisions from the Crash Investigation Sampling System, integrating textual crash reports, structured tabular data, and visual scene diagrams. Phase I generates natural-language crash reconstructions from multimodal inputs. Phase II performs in-depth crash reasoning by combining these reconstructions with temporal Event Data Recorder (EDR).For validation, we applied it to all LVD cases, focusing on a subset of 39 complex crashes where multiple EDR records per collision introduced ambiguity (e.g., due to missing or conflicting data).The evaluation of the 39 LVD crash cases revealed our framework achieved perfect accuracy across all test cases, successfully identifying both the most relevant EDR event and correctly distinguishing striking versus struck vehicles, surpassing the 92% accuracy achieved by human researchers on the same challenging dataset. The system maintained robust performance even when processing incomplete data, including missing or erroneous EDR records and ambiguous scene diagrams. This study demonstrates superior AI capabilities in processing heterogeneous collision data, providing unprecedented precision in reconstructing impact dynamics and characterizing pre-crash behaviors.

item.title: Enhancing Demand-Oriented Regionalization with Agentic AI and Local Heterogeneous Data for Adaptation Planning
item.content:encoded:
Planning units, agentic AI, spatial self-organizing map, disaster planning, flooding risk

Summary:

This article addresses the limitations of conventional planning units such as census tracts and zip codes, which often fail to meet the specific demands of local communities for hazard prevention and disaster response. To overcome these limitations, the authors introduce a planning support system that incorporates agentic AI to create dynamic, demand-oriented planning regions. The system is designed around a novel method called the representative initialized spatially constrained self-organizing map (RepSC-SOM), which enhances traditional self-organizing maps through adaptive geographic filtering and region-growing refinement techniques. This framework allows AI agents to actively participate by reasoning, planning, and guiding users in selecting input features, applying spatial constraints, and supporting interactive exploration. Importantly, the system emphasizes a human-in-the-loop approach to maintain transparency and adaptability, promoting user-driven decision-making in the regionalization process. The effectiveness of the platform is demonstrated through a case study focused on flooding risk management in Jacksonville, Florida. This practical example highlights how the system enables users to interactively generate, explore, and assess new planning regions that better correspond to local hazard risks and community needs, thereby combining computational rigor with practical, user-centered disaster planning solutions.
arXiv:2511.10857v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Conventional planning units or urban regions, such as census tracts, zip codes, or neighborhoods, often do not capture the specific demands of local communities and lack the flexibility to implement effective strategies for hazard prevention or response. To support the creation of dynamic planning units, we introduce a planning support system with agentic AI that enables users to generate demand-oriented regions for disaster planning, integrating the human-in-the-loop principle for transparency and adaptability. The platform is built on a representative initialized spatially constrained self-organizing map (RepSC-SOM), extending traditional SOM with adaptive geographic filtering and region-growing refinement, while AI agents can reason, plan, and act to guide the process by suggesting input features, guiding spatial constraints, and supporting interactive exploration. We demonstrate the capabilities of the platform through a case study on the flooding-related risk in Jacksonville, Florida, showing how it allows users to explore, generate, and evaluate regionalization interactively, combining computational rigor with user-driven decision making.

item.title: LLM enhanced graph inference for long-term disease progression modelling
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Alzheimer's Disease, brain connectivity, disease progression, Large Language Models, tau-PET imaging

Summary:

1. The study addresses the challenge of understanding interactions between biomarkers across brain regions during neurodegenerative diseases, focusing on Alzheimer's Disease (AD).

2. Traditional pathophysiological models generally rely on a single-modality brain connectome as the substrate for disease spreading, resulting in oversimplified and often inaccurate representations of pathology dissemination over time.

3. Purely data-driven methods for learning the underlying propagation graph face identifiability issues due to insufficient constraints.

4. The authors propose a novel framework that integrates Large Language Models (LLMs) as expert knowledge guides to improve learning of disease progression dynamics from irregularly sampled longitudinal data.

5. This approach leverages LLMs' proficiency in synthesizing multi-modal relationships and disease-driving mechanisms, enabling simultaneous optimization of individual disease trajectories and biologically-constrained graph structures with enhanced identifiability.

6. Using tau-PET imaging from an AD cohort, the framework outperforms traditional methods in prediction accuracy and interpretability.

7. The new framework also uncovers additional disease-driving factors beyond what conventional connectivity metrics capture, highlighting its potential for advancing mechanistic understanding of neurodegenerative disease progression.
arXiv:2511.10890v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Understanding the interactions between biomarkers among brain regions during neurodegenerative disease is essential for unravelling the mechanisms underlying disease progression. For example, pathophysiological models of Alzheimer's Disease (AD) typically describe how variables, such as regional levels of toxic proteins, interact spatiotemporally within a dynamical system driven by an underlying biological substrate, often based on brain connectivity. However, current methods grossly oversimplify the complex relationship between brain connectivity by assuming a single-modality brain connectome as the disease-spreading substrate. This leads to inaccurate predictions of pathology spread, especially during the long-term progression period. Meanhwile, other methods of learning such a graph in a purely data-driven way face the identifiability issue due to lack of proper constraint. We thus present a novel framework that uses Large Language Models (LLMs) as expert guides on the interaction of regional variables to enhance learning of disease progression from irregularly sampled longitudinal patient data. By leveraging LLMs' ability to synthesize multi-modal relationships and incorporate diverse disease-driving mechanisms, our method simultaneously optimizes 1) the construction of long-term disease trajectories from individual-level observations and 2) the biologically-constrained graph structure that captures interactions among brain regions with better identifiability. We demonstrate the new approach by estimating the pathology propagation using tau-PET imaging data from an Alzheimer's disease cohort. The new framework demonstrates superior prediction accuracy and interpretability compared to traditional approaches while revealing additional disease-driving factors beyond conventional connectivity measures.

item.title: Multi-Agent Legal Verifier Systems for Data Transfer Planning
item.content:encoded:
Legal compliance, AI-driven data transfer, multi-agent system, Japanese APPI, automated verification

Summary:

This paper addresses the growing importance of legal compliance in AI-driven data transfer planning, particularly under strict privacy regulations like Japan's Act on the Protection of Personal Information (APPI). The authors propose a novel multi-agent legal verifier system that divides compliance checking into specialized agents focusing on statutory interpretation, business context evaluation, and risk assessment. These agents work together through a structured synthesis protocol to provide coordinated reasoning. The approach was evaluated on a carefully stratified dataset containing 200 cases related to Amended APPI Article 16, each with clearly defined ground truth labels. Performance was measured using multiple metrics, where the multi-agent system achieved an overall accuracy of 72%, substantially outperforming a single-agent baseline by 21 percentage points. Notably, the system demonstrated 90% accuracy on clear compliance cases compared to the baseline’s 16%, while maintaining perfect detection of clear violations. Despite challenges in ambiguous cases, the results highlight that domain specialization combined with coordinated reasoning significantly enhances the effectiveness of legal AI systems. This work offers a scalable, regulation-aware framework that supports trustworthy and interpretable automated verification of legal compliance in data transfer scenarios.
arXiv:2511.10925v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Legal compliance in AI-driven data transfer planning is becoming increasingly critical under stringent privacy regulations such as the Japanese Act on the Protection of Personal Information (APPI). We propose a multi-agent legal verifier that decomposes compliance checking into specialized agents for statutory interpretation, business context evaluation, and risk assessment, coordinated through a structured synthesis protocol. Evaluated on a stratified dataset of 200 Amended APPI Article 16 cases with clearly defined ground truth labels and multiple performance metrics, the system achieves 72% accuracy, which is 21 percentage points higher than a single-agent baseline, including 90% accuracy on clear compliance cases (vs. 16% for the baseline) while maintaining perfect detection of clear violations. While challenges remain in ambiguous scenarios, these results show that domain specialization and coordinated reasoning can meaningfully improve legal AI performance, providing a scalable and regulation-aware framework for trustworthy and interpretable automated compliance verification.

item.title: Requirements for Aligned, Dynamic Resolution of Conflicts in Operational Constraints
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: autonomous AI, decision making, operational constraints, normative understanding, aligned behavior

Summary: This paper addresses the challenges faced by deployed autonomous AI systems when they encounter novel or under-specified contexts in which no single course of action fully satisfies all operational constraints such as rules, laws, and goals. It emphasizes the importance of going beyond pre-trained policies by constructing, evaluating, and justifying multiple candidate courses of action. A central requirement for effective decision making in these situations is access to contextual knowledge that may not have been acquired during initial training. The authors characterize the types of knowledge necessary for robust decision making that aligns AI behavior with human expectations and values. By combining normative (ethical and rule-based), pragmatic (practical and goal-oriented), and situational understanding, agents can better assess and select appropriate courses of action in complex real-world scenarios. The paper supports its claims with both theoretical analysis and empirical case studies, illustrating how integrated knowledge improves alignment and robustness in AI decision making. Overall, it contributes to the design principles necessary for autonomous agents to perform reliably and ethically when facing ambiguous or conflicting operational demands.
arXiv:2511.10952v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Deployed, autonomous AI systems must often evaluate multiple plausible courses of action (extended sequences of behavior) in novel or under-specified contexts. Despite extensive training, these systems will inevitably encounter scenarios where no available course of action fully satisfies all operational constraints (e.g., operating procedures, rules, laws, norms, and goals). To achieve goals in accordance with human expectations and values, agents must go beyond their trained policies and instead construct, evaluate, and justify candidate courses of action. These processes require contextual "knowledge" that may lie outside prior (policy) training. This paper characterizes requirements for agent decision making in these contexts. It also identifies the types of knowledge agents require to make decisions robust to agent goals and aligned with human expectations. Drawing on both analysis and empirical case studies, we examine how agents need to integrate normative, pragmatic, and situational understanding to select and then to pursue more aligned courses of action in complex, real-world environments.

item.title: AI Agent-Driven Framework for Automated Product Knowledge Graph Construction in E-Commerce
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Knowledge Graphs, Large Language Models, Ontology, Automated Extraction, E-commerce

Summary: This paper presents a novel, fully automated framework for constructing product knowledge graphs (KGs) directly from unstructured e-commerce product descriptions, addressing the challenges of organizing vast and complex product data. The method leverages Large Language Models (LLMs) through an AI agent-driven approach that operates in three stages: ontology creation and expansion, ontology refinement, and knowledge graph population. Unlike traditional methods, this approach does not rely on predefined schemas or handcrafted extraction rules, enhancing scalability and semantic coherence. The framework has been tested on a real-world dataset of air conditioner product descriptions, achieving impressive results with over 97% property coverage and minimal redundancy. The evaluation demonstrates the system’s effectiveness in generating high-quality ontologies and populating KGs accurately. This work underscores the potential of LLMs to automate structured knowledge extraction processes in the retail domain, enabling intelligent data integration and utilization. Ultimately, the framework provides a scalable, efficient solution for e-commerce platforms to transform unstructured product data into interpretable and actionable knowledge graphs, facilitating improved information retrieval, recommendation systems, and data analytics.
arXiv:2511.11017v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The rapid expansion of e-commerce platforms generates vast amounts of unstructured product data, creating significant challenges for information retrieval, recommendation systems, and data analytics. Knowledge Graphs (KGs) offer a structured, interpretable format to organize such data, yet constructing product-specific KGs remains a complex and manual process. This paper introduces a fully automated, AI agent-driven framework for constructing product knowledge graphs directly from unstructured product descriptions. Leveraging Large Language Models (LLMs), our method operates in three stages using dedicated agents: ontology creation and expansion, ontology refinement, and knowledge graph population. This agent-based approach ensures semantic coherence, scalability, and high-quality output without relying on predefined schemas or handcrafted extraction rules. We evaluate the system on a real-world dataset of air conditioner product descriptions, demonstrating strong performance in both ontology generation and KG population. The framework achieves over 97\% property coverage and minimal redundancy, validating its effectiveness and practical applicability. Our work highlights the potential of LLMs to automate structured knowledge extraction in retail, providing a scalable path toward intelligent product data integration and utilization.

item.title: Faster Symmetry Breaking Constraints for Abstract Structures
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: constraint programming, symmetry breaking, abstract structures, modelling languages, indistinguishable objects

Summary: This paper addresses the challenge of symmetry breaking in constraint programming when dealing with abstract structures like nested sets, which are not natively supported by solvers and must be transformed into other representations such as matrices. Symmetry breaking is essential to reduce redundant search on symmetric solutions, thus significantly speeding up the solving process. Traditional symmetry-breaking methods impose orderings on problem variables to select a canonical representative solution, often the smallest, but these methods become impractical and inefficient when applied directly to abstract variables due to the resulting large and complex constraints. The authors propose a novel, incomplete method that exploits the underlying representations of these abstract structures more effectively to break symmetries, specifically focusing on those arising from indistinguishable objects—a common and important symmetry type. The new approach improves performance and scalability compared to previous methods, such as those introduced by Akgün et al. (2025), by reducing the complexity and size of constraints needed for symmetry breaking. This advancement suggests a promising direction for modeling languages and solvers in tackling symmetry-related inefficiencies in abstract structure constraint problems.
arXiv:2511.11029v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: In constraint programming and related paradigms, a modeller specifies their problem in a modelling language for a solver to search and return its solution(s). Using high-level modelling languages such as Essence, a modeller may express their problems in terms of abstract structures. These are structures not natively supported by the solvers, and so they have to be transformed into or represented as other structures before solving. For example, nested sets are abstract structures, and they can be represented as matrices in constraint solvers. Many problems contain symmetries and one very common and highly successful technique used in constraint programming is to "break" symmetries, to avoid searching for symmetric solutions. This can speed up the solving process by many orders of magnitude. Most of these symmetry-breaking techniques involve placing some kind of ordering for the variables of the problem, and picking a particular member under the symmetries, usually the smallest. Unfortunately, applying this technique to abstract variables produces a very large number of complex constraints that perform poorly in practice. In this paper, we demonstrate a new incomplete method of breaking the symmetries of abstract structures by better exploiting their representations. We apply the method in breaking the symmetries arising from indistinguishable objects, a commonly occurring type of symmetry, and show that our method is faster than the previous methods proposed in (Akg\"un et al. 2025).

item.title: Key Decision-Makers in Multi-Agent Debates: Who Holds the Power?
item.content:encoded:
Multi-Agent Debate, Role Allocation, Truth Last, Consistency, Reasoning Tasks

Summary:

This study investigates the impact of role allocation strategies within Multi-Agent Debate (MAD) frameworks on the reasoning abilities of large language models (LLMs). It identifies that assigning distinct viewpoints to specific roles crucially influences MAD performance in reasoning tasks. One key contribution is the introduction of a novel role allocation strategy called "Truth Last," which improves reasoning accuracy by up to 22%. Addressing the challenge of uncertain truth in practical contexts, the researchers propose the Multi-Agent Debate Consistency (MADC) strategy. MADC systematically simulates and optimizes core mechanisms using path consistency to evaluate agreement among independent agent roles, designating the role with the highest consistency score as representing the truth. The approach was empirically validated on nine different LLMs, including DeepSeek-R1 distilled models, across difficult reasoning tasks. Results show that MADC consistently outperforms baseline MAD strategies, effectively breaking through prior performance bottlenecks. This work offers a vital advancement toward enhancing the scalability and reasoning performance of LLM agents by refining role assignment and consensus mechanisms within multi-agent debates.
arXiv:2511.11040v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Recent studies on LLM agent scaling have highlighted the potential of Multi-Agent Debate (MAD) to enhance reasoning abilities. However, the critical aspect of role allocation strategies remains underexplored. In this study, we demonstrate that allocating roles with differing viewpoints to specific positions significantly impacts MAD's performance in reasoning tasks. Specifically, we find a novel role allocation strategy, "Truth Last", which can improve MAD performance by up to 22% in reasoning tasks. To address the issue of unknown truth in practical applications, we propose the Multi-Agent Debate Consistency (MADC) strategy, which systematically simulates and optimizes its core mechanisms. MADC incorporates path consistency to assess agreement among independent roles, simulating the role with the highest consistency score as the truth. We validated MADC across a range of LLMs (9 models), including the DeepSeek-R1 Distilled Models, on challenging reasoning tasks. MADC consistently demonstrated advanced performance, effectively overcoming MAD's performance bottlenecks and providing a crucial pathway for further improvements in LLM agent scaling.

item.title: Autonomous Vehicle Path Planning by Searching With Differentiable Simulation
item.content:encoded:
Planning, differentiable simulation, autonomous driving, gradient descent, path planning

Summary:

This paper presents Differentiable Simulation for Search (DSS), a novel framework designed to improve planning in autonomous driving scenarios. Planning is essential for safely refining actions before execution in complex and dense traffic environments, helping to avoid collisions. DSS leverages a differentiable simulator called Waymax, which serves dual roles as both a next-state predictor and a critic within the planning process. Unlike traditional learned models, Waymax’s hardcoded dynamics enable highly accurate state predictions. The differentiability of the simulator allows the DSS agent to optimize action sequences using gradient descent over imagined future trajectories, effectively searching through possible actions. This contrasts with methods relying solely on policy learning, sequence prediction, or model-free reinforcement learning. Experimentally, DSS demonstrates significant improvements in tracking accuracy and path planning compared to previous approaches including imitation learning and stochastic search alone. By combining gradient-based optimization with stochastic search, DSS offers a powerful planning strategy that harnesses accurate simulation dynamics to better anticipate future states and outcomes. This approach is particularly suited to the challenges of autonomous driving, where precise and reliable planning under uncertainty is critical for safety and performance.
arXiv:2511.11043v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Planning allows an agent to safely refine its actions before executing them in the real world. In autonomous driving, this is crucial to avoid collisions and navigate in complex, dense traffic scenarios. One way to plan is to search for the best action sequence. However, this is challenging when all necessary components - policy, next-state predictor, and critic - have to be learned. Here we propose Differentiable Simulation for Search (DSS), a framework that leverages the differentiable simulator Waymax as both a next state predictor and a critic. It relies on the simulator's hardcoded dynamics, making state predictions highly accurate, while utilizing the simulator's differentiability to effectively search across action sequences. Our DSS agent optimizes its actions using gradient descent over imagined future trajectories. We show experimentally that DSS - the combination of planning gradients and stochastic search - significantly improves tracking and path planning accuracy compared to sequence prediction, imitation learning, model-free RL, and other planning methods.

item.title: ARCTraj: A Dataset and Benchmark of Human Reasoning Trajectories for Abstract Problem Solving
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: ARCTraj, human reasoning, Abstraction and Reasoning Corpus, Markov decision process, reinforcement learning

Summary: 1. The paper introduces ARCTraj, a novel dataset and methodological framework designed to model human reasoning during complex visual tasks within the Abstraction and Reasoning Corpus (ARC). 2. Unlike existing approaches that depend solely on static input-output pairs, ARCTraj records temporally ordered, object-level actions, allowing insight into intermediate reasoning steps and how human reasoning evolves over time. 3. The dataset, collected via the O2ARC web interface, includes approximately 10,000 annotated trajectories with task identifiers, timestamps, and success labels, spanning 400 training tasks from the ARC-AGI-1 benchmark. 4. ARCTraj defines a unified reasoning pipeline that covers data collection, action abstraction, formulation as a Markov decision process (MDP), and supports integration with advanced downstream techniques such as reinforcement learning (e.g., PPO), generative models (World Models, GFlowNets, Diffusion agents), and sequence modeling (Decision Transformers). 5. Through analysis of spatial selection, color attribution, and strategic convergence, the work reveals key structural aspects and diversity in human reasoning, positioning ARCTraj as a foundational resource to enhance explainability, alignment, and development of more generalizable, human-like intelligence models.
arXiv:2511.11079v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We present ARCTraj, a dataset and methodological framework for modeling human reasoning through complex visual tasks in the Abstraction and Reasoning Corpus (ARC). While ARC has inspired extensive research on abstract reasoning, most existing approaches rely on static input--output supervision, which limits insight into how reasoning unfolds over time. ARCTraj addresses this gap by recording temporally ordered, object-level actions that capture how humans iteratively transform inputs into outputs, revealing intermediate reasoning steps that conventional datasets overlook. Collected via the O2ARC web interface, it contains around 10,000 trajectories annotated with task identifiers, timestamps, and success labels across 400 training tasks from the ARC-AGI-1 benchmark. It further defines a unified reasoning pipeline encompassing data collection, action abstraction, Markov decision process (MDP) formulation, and downstream learning, enabling integration with reinforcement learning, generative modeling, and sequence modeling methods such as PPO, World Models, GFlowNets, Diffusion agents, and Decision Transformers. Analyses of spatial selection, color attribution, and strategic convergence highlight the structure and diversity of human reasoning. Together, these contributions position ARCTraj as a structured and interpretable foundation for studying human-like reasoning, advancing explainability, alignment, and generalizable intelligence.

item.title: Satisficing and Optimal Generalised Planning via Goal Regression (Extended Version)
item.content:encoded:
Generalised planning, goal regression, first-order rules, state space pruning, optimal plans

Summary: The paper introduces a novel and straightforward approach to generalised planning (GP), which is the process of synthesising programs capable of solving families of related planning problems. The method begins by taking a set of training problems and for each problem computing an optimal plan for each goal atom in a specified order. Then, goal regression is applied to these plans to derive corresponding outputs that are lifted into first-order “Condition → Actions” rules. These rules together form a generalised plan that can either be executed directly or used to prune the search space in planning tasks. The authors formalise the theoretical framework and define the specific conditions under which their method guarantees the validity of the generalised plans produced, along with axioms related to state space pruning in search algorithms. Experimental results demonstrate that this approach yields significant improvements compared to state-of-the-art generalised planners. Improvements are measured across three key criteria: synthesis cost, planning coverage, and solution quality. The evaluation incorporates a variety of classical and numeric planning domains, illustrating the broad applicability and effectiveness of the method in enhancing planning efficiency and performance.
arXiv:2511.11095v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Generalised planning (GP) refers to the task of synthesising programs that solve families of related planning problems. We introduce a novel, yet simple method for GP: given a set of training problems, for each problem, compute an optimal plan for each goal atom in some order, perform goal regression on the resulting plans, and lift the corresponding outputs to obtain a set of first-order $\textit{Condition} \rightarrow \textit{Actions}$ rules. The rules collectively constitute a generalised plan that can be executed as is or alternatively be used to prune the planning search space. We formalise and prove the conditions under which our method is guaranteed to learn valid generalised plans and state space pruning axioms for search. Experiments demonstrate significant improvements over state-of-the-art (generalised) planners with respect to the 3 metrics of synthesis cost, planning coverage, and solution quality on various classical and numeric planning domains.

item.title: GGBench: A Geometric Generative Reasoning Benchmark for Unified Multimodal Models
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Unified Multimodal Models, generative reasoning, geometric construction, benchmark, GGBench

Summary:

The paper introduces the concept of Unified Multimodal Models (UMMs), which represent a significant shift in AI by enabling active cross-modal generation instead of mere passive perception. Despite UMMs' advanced capabilities in synthesizing information, existing evaluation methods fall short as they usually focus separately on either discriminative understanding or unconstrained image generation, without addressing their combined reasoning ability. To address this gap, the authors propose geometric construction as an ideal domain to test integrated generative reasoning because it inherently requires the fusion of language comprehension and precise visual generation. They present GGBench, a new benchmark specifically designed to evaluate a model’s capacity for geometric generative reasoning. GGBench offers a structured framework that allows systematic diagnosis of a model's skills in understanding, reasoning, and actively generating constructive solutions. By integrating language understanding and visual generation evaluation, this benchmark sets a more rigorous standard for assessing next-generation intelligent systems and promotes research aimed at deeper cognitive abilities in AI. The project website provides access to the benchmark and additional resources.
arXiv:2511.11134v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The advent of Unified Multimodal Models (UMMs) signals a paradigm shift in artificial intelligence, moving from passive perception to active, cross-modal generation. Despite their unprecedented ability to synthesize information, a critical gap persists in evaluation: existing benchmarks primarily assess discriminative understanding or unconstrained image generation separately, failing to measure the integrated cognitive process of generative reasoning. To bridge this gap, we propose that geometric construction provides an ideal testbed as it inherently demands a fusion of language comprehension and precise visual generation. We introduce GGBench, a benchmark designed specifically to evaluate geometric generative reasoning. It provides a comprehensive framework for systematically diagnosing a model's ability to not only understand and reason but to actively construct a solution, thereby setting a more rigorous standard for the next generation of intelligent systems. Project website: https://opendatalab-raiser.github.io/GGBench/.

item.title: Multi-agent Undercover Gaming: Hallucination Removal via Counterfactual Test for Multimodal Reasoning
item.content:encoded:
hallucination, multi-agent debate, multimodal reasoning, counterfactual testing, large language models

Summary:

This paper addresses the persistent issue of hallucination in large language models (LLMs) that hampers their reasoning accuracy. It critiques the existing Multi-Agent Debate (MAD) paradigm for assuming all debaters are rational and reflective, which is unrealistic when agents may hallucinate themselves. To overcome this, the authors propose the Multi-agent Undercover Gaming (MUG) protocol, inspired by social deduction games such as "Who is Undercover?". MUG innovatively recasts the problem as detecting hallucinating "undercover" agents using multimodal counterfactual tests. Specifically, it modifies reference images to introduce counterfactual evidence and checks if agents can detect these alterations accurately, thus providing ground-truth identification of hallucinating agents. The approach advances MAD in three major ways: (1) enabling factual verification beyond mere statistical consensus by applying counterfactual testing, (2) facilitating cross-evidence reasoning through dynamically modified evidence rather than static inputs, and (3) promoting active reasoning where agents engage in probing discussions instead of passively responding. Overall, MUG offers a more dependable and effective framework for multimodal reasoning in LLMs. The authors have made the source code publicly available at https://github.com/YongLD/MUG.git.
arXiv:2511.11182v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Hallucination continues to pose a major obstacle in the reasoning capabilities of large language models (LLMs). Although the Multi-Agent Debate (MAD) paradigm offers a promising solution by promoting consensus among multiple agents to enhance reliability, it relies on the unrealistic assumption that all debaters are rational and reflective, which is a condition that may not hold when agents themselves are prone to hallucinations. To address this gap, we introduce the Multi-agent Undercover Gaming (MUG) protocol, inspired by social deduction games like "Who is Undercover?". MUG reframes MAD as a process of detecting "undercover" agents (those suffering from hallucinations) by employing multimodal counterfactual tests. Specifically, we modify reference images to introduce counterfactual evidence and observe whether agents can accurately identify these changes, providing ground-truth for identifying hallucinating agents and enabling robust, crowd-powered multimodal reasoning. MUG advances MAD protocols along three key dimensions: (1) enabling factual verification beyond statistical consensus through counterfactual testing; (2) introducing cross-evidence reasoning via dynamically modified evidence sources instead of relying on static inputs; and (3) fostering active reasoning, where agents engage in probing discussions rather than passively answering questions. Collectively, these innovations offer a more reliable and effective framework for multimodal reasoning in LLMs. The source code can be accessed at https://github.com/YongLD/MUG.git.

item.title: STaR: Towards Cognitive Table Reasoning via Slow-Thinking Large Language Models
item.content:encoded:
Table reasoning, large language models, slow-thinking, reinforcement learning, uncertainty quantification

Summary: This paper addresses key limitations in table reasoning using large language models (LLMs), focusing on improving the depth and stability of the reasoning process. The authors introduce STaR (slow-thinking for table reasoning), a novel framework that equips LLMs with slow-thinking capabilities by modeling step-by-step reasoning and incorporating uncertainty-aware inference. STaR uses a two-stage difficulty-aware reinforcement learning (DRL) approach during training, which enables the model to progressively learn from simple to complex queries using a composite reward system. During inference, it integrates token-level confidence and answer consistency to quantify uncertainty at the trajectory level, allowing the selection of more credible reasoning paths. Extensive experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that STaR outperforms existing methods in accuracy and reasoning stability. Additionally, the framework shows strong generalization to out-of-domain datasets, highlighting its robustness and versatility. Overall, STaR represents a cognitively inspired and reliable approach to enhancing table reasoning capabilities in LLMs, addressing both the depth and reliability challenges inherent in this task.
arXiv:2511.11233v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Table reasoning with the large language models (LLMs) is a fundamental path toward building intelligent systems that can understand and analyze over structured data. While recent progress has shown promising results, they still suffer from two key limitations: (i) the reasoning processes lack the depth and iterative refinement characteristic of human cognition; and (ii) the reasoning processes exhibit instability, which compromises their reliability in downstream applications. In this work, we present STaR (slow-thinking for table reasoning), a new framework achieving cognitive table reasoning, in which LLMs are equipped with slow-thinking capabilities by explicitly modeling step-by-step thinking and uncertainty-aware inference. During training, STaR employs two-stage difficulty-aware reinforcement learning (DRL), progressively learning from simple to complex queries under a composite reward. During inference, STaR performs trajectory-level uncertainty quantification by integrating token-level confidence and answer consistency, enabling selection of more credible reasoning paths. Extensive experiments on benchmarks demonstrate that STaR achieves superior performance and enhanced reasoning stability. Moreover, strong generalization over out-of-domain datasets further demonstrates STaR's potential as a reliable and cognitively inspired solution for table reasoning with LLMs.

item.title: UAVBench: An Open Benchmark Dataset for Autonomous and Agentic AI UAV Systems via LLM-Generated Flight Scenarios
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: UAVBench, large language models, autonomous aerial systems, UAV reasoning, benchmark dataset

Summary:

This paper introduces UAVBench, an open benchmark dataset designed to evaluate the reasoning capabilities of large language models (LLMs) in autonomous unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) systems. UAVBench consists of 50,000 UAV flight scenarios generated using taxonomy-guided LLM prompting combined with multi-stage safety validation to ensure scenario reliability. Each scenario is structured in JSON format and includes mission objectives, vehicle configurations, environmental conditions, and quantitative risk labels to facilitate a unified representation. The authors extend UAVBench with UAVBench_MCQ, a reasoning-oriented dataset of 50,000 multiple-choice questions covering ten cognitive and ethical reasoning domains such as aerodynamics, navigation, multi-agent coordination, and integrated reasoning. The framework enables interpretable and machine-checkable evaluation of UAV-specific cognition within realistic operational contexts. Evaluation on 32 state-of-the-art LLMs, including GPT-5 and ChatGPT-4o, reveals strong capabilities in perception and policy reasoning but highlights ongoing challenges in ethics-aware judgment and resource-limited decision-making. UAVBench thus establishes a reproducible and physically grounded foundation for benchmarking agentic AI in autonomous aerial systems. All datasets, benchmarks, evaluation scripts, and related materials are openly available on GitHub to encourage further research and development in next-generation UAV reasoning intelligence.
arXiv:2511.11252v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Autonomous aerial systems increasingly rely on large language models (LLMs) for mission planning, perception, and decision-making, yet the lack of standardized and physically grounded benchmarks limits systematic evaluation of their reasoning capabilities. To address this gap, we introduce UAVBench, an open benchmark dataset comprising 50,000 validated UAV flight scenarios generated through taxonomy-guided LLM prompting and multi-stage safety validation. Each scenario is encoded in a structured JSON schema that includes mission objectives, vehicle configuration, environmental conditions, and quantitative risk labels, providing a unified representation of UAV operations across diverse domains. Building on this foundation, we present UAVBench_MCQ, a reasoning-oriented extension containing 50,000 multiple-choice questions spanning ten cognitive and ethical reasoning styles, ranging from aerodynamics and navigation to multi-agent coordination and integrated reasoning. This framework enables interpretable and machine-checkable assessment of UAV-specific cognition under realistic operational contexts. We evaluate 32 state-of-the-art LLMs, including GPT-5, ChatGPT-4o, Gemini 2.5 Flash, DeepSeek V3, Qwen3 235B, and ERNIE 4.5 300B, and find strong performance in perception and policy reasoning but persistent challenges in ethics-aware and resource-constrained decision-making. UAVBench establishes a reproducible and physically grounded foundation for benchmarking agentic AI in autonomous aerial systems and advancing next-generation UAV reasoning intelligence. To support open science and reproducibility, we release the UAVBench dataset, the UAVBench_MCQ benchmark, evaluation scripts, and all related materials on GitHub at https://github.com/maferrag/UAVBench

item.title: AIonopedia: an LLM agent orchestrating multimodal learning for ionic liquid discovery
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Ionic Liquids, Large Language Models, Property Prediction, Molecular Screening, Wet-lab Validation

Summary: The paper addresses the challenges in discovering new Ionic Liquids (ILs), which include limited data availability, low predictive accuracy of models, and fragmented workflows. To overcome these issues, the authors introduce AIonopedia, the first Large Language Model (LLM) agent specifically designed for IL discovery. AIonopedia is built upon a multimodal domain foundation model augmented by an LLM, enabling it to perform accurate property predictions for ILs. It features a hierarchical search architecture that facilitates efficient molecular screening and design processes. The model has been trained and evaluated on a newly curated and comprehensive dataset of ILs, demonstrating superior performance compared to existing methods. Further evaluations using literature-reported IL systems confirm AIonopedia’s ability to effectively modify ILs, supporting its reliability and versatility. Beyond computational experiments, the practical utility of AIonopedia was validated through wet-lab experiments, where it exhibited exceptional generalization abilities when handling challenging out-of-distribution IL discovery tasks. These results collectively highlight AIonopedia’s potential to significantly accelerate real-world discovery and optimization of novel Ionic Liquids.
arXiv:2511.11257v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The discovery of novel Ionic Liquids (ILs) is hindered by critical challenges in property prediction, including limited data, poor model accuracy, and fragmented workflows. Leveraging the power of Large Language Models (LLMs), we introduce AIonopedia, to the best of our knowledge, the first LLM agent for IL discovery. Powered by an LLM-augmented multimodal domain foundation model for ILs, AIonopedia enables accurate property predictions and incorporates a hierarchical search architecture for molecular screening and design. Trained and evaluated on a newly curated and comprehensive IL dataset, our model delivers superior performance. Complementing these results, evaluations on literature-reported systems indicate that the agent can perform effective IL modification. Moving beyond offline tests, the practical efficacy was further confirmed through real-world wet-lab validation, in which the agent demonstrated exceptional generalization capabilities on challenging out-of-distribution tasks, underscoring its ability to accelerate real-world IL discovery.

item.title: A Workflow for Full Traceability of AI Decisions
item.content:encoded:
Traceability, AI decisions, documentation, confidential computing, accountability

Summary: This paper addresses the critical issue of insufficient documentation in AI decision-making processes, which impedes traceability and accountability, especially when decisions affect human well-being or rights. The authors propose a radical yet practical solution by enforcing comprehensive documentation for every component involved in AI training and inference. They introduce the first operational workflow designed to generate tamper-proof, verifiable, and exhaustive records of AI decisions, thereby facilitating responsibility tracing and legal scrutiny. The approach extends the existing Data-Bound Object Model (DBOM) concept into a functional workflow that employs confidential computing technology to enhance security and integrity of documentation. To demonstrate the practical application of their system, the authors develop an app designed to distinguish poisonous mushrooms from edible ones, serving as a playful but high-stakes example of decision support. This exemplification underscores the workflow’s effectiveness in real-world scenarios where AI decisions can have serious consequences. Overall, the paper contributes a robust framework aimed at increasing transparency, accountability, and legal defensibility of automated AI decisions through meticulous and secure documentation.
arXiv:2511.11275v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: An ever increasing number of high-stake decisions are made or assisted by automated systems employing brittle artificial intelligence technology. There is a substantial risk that some of these decision induce harm to people, by infringing their well-being or their fundamental human rights. The state-of-the-art in AI systems makes little effort with respect to appropriate documentation of the decision process. This obstructs the ability to trace what went into a decision, which in turn is a prerequisite to any attempt of reconstructing a responsibility chain. Specifically, such traceability is linked to a documentation that will stand up in court when determining the cause of some AI-based decision that inadvertently or intentionally violates the law. This paper takes a radical, yet practical, approach to this problem, by enforcing the documentation of each and every component that goes into the training or inference of an automated decision. As such, it presents the first running workflow supporting the generation of tamper-proof, verifiable and exhaustive traces of AI decisions. In doing so, we expand the DBOM concept into an effective running workflow leveraging confidential computing technology. We demonstrate the inner workings of the workflow in the development of an app to tell poisonous and edible mushrooms apart, meant as a playful example of high-stake decision support.

item.title: Can You Tell the Difference? Contrastive Explanations for ABox Entailments
item.content:encoded:
Contrastive explanations, ABox reasoning, description logics, computational complexity, ontology

Summary: This article introduces the concept of contrastive ABox explanations designed to answer queries like "Why is a an instance of C, but b is not?" Unlike traditional approaches that explain positive or negative entailments separately, contrastive explanations handle both simultaneously, enabling a focus on the relevant similarities and differences between individuals a and b. The work develops a formal framework for such explanations specifically within the context of ABox reasoning using description logic ontologies. It further investigates the computational complexity of generating these explanations under various optimality criteria and across different description logics, from lightweight to more expressive ones. Additionally, the authors present an initial implementation targeting one variant of contrastive explanations, demonstrating the practical feasibility of their approach. Experimental evaluation is conducted on generated test cases reflective of realistic knowledge bases, providing initial insights into effectiveness and efficiency. This research thereby contributes both theoretically and practically to the field of ontology-based knowledge explanation by enabling more nuanced and informative contrastive reasoning capabilities.
arXiv:2511.11281v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We introduce the notion of contrastive ABox explanations to answer questions of the type "Why is a an instance of C, but b is not?". While there are various approaches for explaining positive entailments (why is C(a) entailed by the knowledge base) as well as missing entailments (why is C(b) not entailed) in isolation, contrastive explanations consider both at the same time, which allows them to focus on the relevant commonalities and differences between a and b. We develop an appropriate notion of contrastive explanations for the special case of ABox reasoning with description logic ontologies, and analyze the computational complexity for different variants under different optimality criteria, considering lightweight as well as more expressive description logics. We implemented a first method for computing one variant of contrastive explanations, and evaluated it on generated problems for realistic knowledge bases.

item.title: EcoAlign: An Economically Rational Framework for Efficient LVLM Alignment
item.content:encoded:
jailbreak vulnerabilities, alignment, economic efficiency, LVLM, EcoAlign

Summary: Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs) demonstrate strong reasoning capabilities but face complex jailbreak vulnerabilities that pose significant safety challenges. The alignment of LVLMs goes beyond just safety concerns; it also implicates economic efficiency because current alignment methods must balance safety, utility, and operational costs. Existing approaches focus primarily on the final outputs, a process-blind strategy that wastes computational resources on unsafe reasoning that can be hidden beneath seemingly benign justifications, which evades simple safety measures. To resolve this, the authors introduce EcoAlign, an inference-time framework that treats LVLM alignment as an economically rational search problem by modeling the LVLM as a boundedly rational agent. EcoAlign incrementally explores a thought graph and scores potential actions with a forward-looking function similar to net present value, dynamically weighing expected safety, utility, and costs against the remaining computational budget. To counteract potential deception, safety along reasoning paths is ensured by applying the weakest-link principle. The framework was tested extensively across three closed-source and two open-source LVLMs, using six datasets, where it achieved safety and utility performance that matches or exceeds state-of-the-art methods while reducing computational costs. EcoAlign thus offers a principled and economical solution for robust alignment of LVLMs.
arXiv:2511.11301v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs) exhibit powerful reasoning capabilities but suffer sophisticated jailbreak vulnerabilities. Fundamentally, aligning LVLMs is not just a safety challenge but a problem of economic efficiency. Current alignment methods struggle with the trade-off between safety, utility, and operational costs. Critically, a focus solely on final outputs (process-blindness) wastes significant computational budget on unsafe deliberation. This flaw allows harmful reasoning to be disguised with benign justifications, thereby circumventing simple additive safety scores. To address this, we propose EcoAlign, an inference-time framework that reframes alignment as an economically rational search by treating the LVLM as a boundedly rational agent. EcoAlign incrementally expands a thought graph and scores actions using a forward-looking function (analogous to net present value) that dynamically weighs expected safety, utility, and cost against the remaining budget. To prevent deception, path safety is enforced via the weakest-link principle. Extensive experiments across 3 closed-source and 2 open-source models on 6 datasets show that EcoAlign matches or surpasses state-of-the-art safety and utility at a lower computational cost, thereby offering a principled, economical pathway to robust LVLM alignment.

item.title: RLSLM: A Hybrid Reinforcement Learning Framework Aligning Rule-Based Social Locomotion Model with Human Social Norms
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: social navigation, reinforcement learning, social locomotion model, human comfort, VR experiment

Summary: Navigating environments populated by humans without causing discomfort is a crucial skill for socially-aware agents. Traditional rule-based methods provide interpretability based on predefined psychological principles but often lack flexibility and generalizability. On the other hand, purely data-driven techniques can learn intricate behaviors from large datasets but tend to be inefficient, opaque, and hard to align with human expectations. To address these challenges, the authors introduce RLSLM, a hybrid reinforcement learning framework that incorporates a rule-based Social Locomotion Model derived from empirical behavioral studies into its reward function.
