They design an adjustable multiplier that enables adaptive selection of the appropriate RKHS corresponding to hyperbolic spaces with any curvature. Building on this framework, they develop a family of adaptive hyperbolic kernels, including a new adaptive hyperbolic radial kernel, whose parameters can be learned to modulate hyperbolic features in a task-specific manner. Extensive experiments on benchmark datasets in both visual and language domains demonstrate that the proposed adaptive hyperbolic kernels outperform existing hyperbolic kernel methods in modeling hierarchical dependencies, confirming their effectiveness and flexibility in practical applications.
arXiv:2511.09921v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Hierarchical data pervades diverse machine learning applications, including natural language processing, computer vision, and social network analysis. Hyperbolic space, characterized by its negative curvature, has demonstrated strong potential in such tasks due to its capacity to embed hierarchical structures with minimal distortion. Previous evidence indicates that the hyperbolic representation capacity can be further enhanced through kernel methods. However, existing hyperbolic kernels still suffer from mild geometric distortion or lack adaptability. This paper addresses these issues by introducing a curvature-aware de Branges-Rovnyak space, a reproducing kernel Hilbert space (RKHS) that is isometric to a Poincare ball. We design an adjustable multiplier to select the appropriate RKHS corresponding to the hyperbolic space with any curvature adaptively. Building on this foundation, we further construct a family of adaptive hyperbolic kernels, including the novel adaptive hyperbolic radial kernel, whose learnable parameters modulate hyperbolic features in a task-aware manner. Extensive experiments on visual and language benchmarks demonstrate that our proposed kernels outperform existing hyperbolic kernels in modeling hierarchical dependencies.

item.title: SPAN: Benchmarking and Improving Cross-Calendar Temporal Reasoning of Large Language Models
item.content:encoded:
arXiv:2511.09993v1 Keywords: SPAN benchmark, cross-calendar reasoning, temporal conversion, LLM evaluation, tool-augmented code generation

Summary: We introduce SPAN, a novel benchmark designed for cross-calendar temporal reasoning, requiring large language models (LLMs) to perform both intra-calendar temporal reasoning and inter-calendar temporal conversion across six different calendars. SPAN includes ten reasoning directions, two reasoning types, and two question formats to comprehensively evaluate LLM temporal understanding. To ensure dynamic and contamination-free testing, a template-driven protocol is proposed allowing instance generation based on user-specified Gregorian dates. Extensive experiments were conducted on state-of-the-art open- and closed-source LLMs over a date range from 1960 to 2060, revealing persistent challenges as these models achieved only an average accuracy of 34.5%, with none surpassing 80%. Analysis identifies two primary obstacles: Future-Date Degradation, where performance declines on future dates, and Calendar Asymmetry Bias, reflecting uneven proficiency across calendars. To address these challenges, the study develops an LLM-powered Time Agent utilizing tool-augmented code generation, significantly improving cross-calendar temporal reasoning performance. The Time Agent achieves an average accuracy of 95.31%, notably outperforming competitive baselines. This work highlights the potential for combining LLMs with external tools and code to advance culturally and temporally adaptive temporal reasoning capabilities in AI systems, encouraging continued research in this area.
arXiv:2511.09993v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We introduce SPAN, a cross-calendar temporal reasoning benchmark, which requires LLMs to perform intra-calendar temporal reasoning and inter-calendar temporal conversion. SPAN features ten cross-calendar temporal reasoning directions, two reasoning types, and two question formats across six calendars. To enable time-variant and contamination-free evaluation, we propose a template-driven protocol for dynamic instance generation that enables assessment on a user-specified Gregorian date. We conduct extensive experiments on both open- and closed-source state-of-the-art (SOTA) LLMs over a range of dates spanning 100 years from 1960 to 2060. Our evaluations show that these LLMs achieve an average accuracy of only 34.5%, with none exceeding 80%, indicating that this task remains challenging. Through in-depth analysis of reasoning types, question formats, and temporal reasoning directions, we identify two key obstacles for LLMs: Future-Date Degradation and Calendar Asymmetry Bias. To strengthen LLMs' cross-calendar temporal reasoning capability, we further develop an LLM-powered Time Agent that leverages tool-augmented code generation. Empirical results show that Time Agent achieves an average accuracy of 95.31%, outperforming several competitive baselines, highlighting the potential of tool-augmented code generation to advance cross-calendar temporal reasoning. We hope this work will inspire further efforts toward more temporally and culturally adaptive LLMs.

item.title: ChEmREF: Evaluating Language Model Readiness for Chemical Emergency Response
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: HAZMAT, language models, emergency response, chemical representation, ChEmREF

Summary:

1. Emergency responders at HAZMAT incidents need to make rapid, critical decisions but currently rely on manually searching extensive chemical guidelines. 2. The study explores the capability of modern language models to aid responders by understanding chemical information quickly and accurately, identifying hazards, and generating response recommendations. 3. Researchers introduce the Chemical Emergency Response Evaluation Framework (ChEmREF), a benchmark consisting of 1,035 HAZMAT chemicals from the Emergency Response Guidebook and PubChem Database, structured into three tasks: translation between chemical representations, emergency response recommendation generation, and domain-specific question answering. 4. Evaluation results indicate the best models achieved 68.0% exact match accuracy in chemical representation translation, a 52.7% LLM Judge score for emergency response recommendations, and 63.9% accuracy on HAZMAT exam multiple-choice questions. 5. These outcomes demonstrate that language models hold promise for supporting emergency responders in complex chemical hazard tasks but still require careful human supervision due to current performance limitations.
arXiv:2511.10027v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Emergency responders managing hazardous material HAZMAT incidents face critical, time-sensitive decisions, manually navigating extensive chemical guidelines. We investigate whether today's language models can assist responders by rapidly and reliably understanding critical information, identifying hazards, and providing recommendations.We introduce the Chemical Emergency Response Evaluation Framework (ChEmREF), a new benchmark comprising questions on 1,035 HAZMAT chemicals from the Emergency Response Guidebook and the PubChem Database. ChEmREF is organized into three tasks: (1) translation of chemical representation between structured and unstructured forms (e.g., converting C2H6O to ethanol), (2) emergency response generation (e.g., recommending appropriate evacuation distances) and (3) domain knowledge question answering from chemical safety and certification exams. Our best evaluated models received an exact match of 68.0% on unstructured HAZMAT chemical representation translation, a LLM Judge score of 52.7% on incident response recommendations, and a multiple-choice accuracy of 63.9% on HAMZAT examinations.These findings suggest that while language models show potential to assist emergency responders in various tasks, they require careful human oversight due to their current limitations.

item.title: Beyond ReAct: A Planner-Centric Framework for Complex Tool-Augmented LLM Reasoning
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Planner-centric, Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG), multi-tool coordination, Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT), Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO)

Summary: The paper addresses significant challenges faced by existing tool-augmented large language models (LLMs) when processing complex queries, particularly the local optimization traps inherent in current incremental decision-making frameworks like ReAct. To overcome these limitations, the authors propose a novel Planner-centric Plan-Execute paradigm, which introduces a Planner model that performs global Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) planning. This architectural innovation enables optimized execution by coordinating multiple tools beyond conventional sequential approaches. They further contribute ComplexTool-Plan, a large-scale benchmark dataset designed to test sophisticated multi-tool composition and coordination abilities required for handling intricate queries. To enhance Planner performance, a two-stage training methodology is developed, combining Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) and Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO). This approach systematically improves the Planner’s accuracy in tool selection and global planning through structured DAG-based planning. When integrated with a powerful executor, the proposed framework achieves state-of-the-art results on the StableToolBench benchmark. The system demonstrates superior end-to-end execution capabilities and robustness in managing complex multi-tool workflows, highlighting its effectiveness in addressing the challenges of complex query processing in tool-augmented LLMs.
arXiv:2511.10037v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Existing tool-augmented large language models (LLMs) encounter significant challenges when processing complex queries. Current frameworks such as ReAct are prone to local optimization traps due to their reliance on incremental decision-making processes. To address these limitations, we propose a novel Planner-centric Plan-Execute paradigm that fundamentally resolves local optimization bottlenecks through architectural innovation. Central to our approach is a novel Planner model that performs global Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) planning for complex queries, enabling optimized execution beyond conventional tool coordination. We also introduce ComplexTool-Plan, a large-scale benchmark dataset featuring complex queries that demand sophisticated multi-tool composition and coordination capabilities. Additionally, we develop a two-stage training methodology that integrates Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) with Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO), systematically enhancing the Planner's tool selection accuracy and global planning awareness through structured DAG-based planning. When integrated with a capable executor, our framework achieves state-of-the-art performance on the StableToolBench benchmark for complex user queries, demonstrating superior end-to-end execution capabilities and robust handling of intricate multi-tool workflows.

item.title: Efficient Thought Space Exploration through Strategic Intervention
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: large language models, reasoning, Hint-Practice Reasoning, Distributional Inconsistency Reduction, efficiency-accuracy tradeoff

Summary: This paper introduces the Hint-Practice Reasoning (HPR) framework to improve reasoning efficiency in large language models (LLMs). The authors observe that most next-token predictions by LLMs match the golden output except at a few critical points causing errors. Based on this, HPR employs two components: a "hinter," a powerful LLM providing probabilistic hints at critical decision points, and a "practitioner," a smaller efficient model handling primary reasoning steps. The core innovation is Distributional Inconsistency Reduction (DIR), a metric that dynamically detects intervention points by measuring the divergence between the practitioner's reasoning path and the hinter's expected token distribution in a tree-structured probabilistic space. The framework iteratively updates this reasoning tree, emphasizing likely reasoning paths and pruning unlikely branches, thereby reducing exhaustive sampling. Experimental results demonstrate that HPR achieves state-of-the-art efficiency-accuracy tradeoffs on both arithmetic and commonsense reasoning benchmarks. It matches the performance of self-consistency and Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS) methods while decoding only one-fifth of tokens. Further, HPR outperforms existing methods by up to 5.1% in absolute accuracy with comparable or reduced computational cost (FLOPs). Overall, HPR offers a theoretically grounded, efficient approach to enhance reasoning speed without sacrificing accuracy in large language models.
arXiv:2511.10038v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: While large language models (LLMs) demonstrate emerging reasoning capabilities, current inference-time expansion methods incur prohibitive computational costs by exhaustive sampling. Through analyzing decoding trajectories, we observe that most next-token predictions align well with the golden output, except for a few critical tokens that lead to deviations. Inspired by this phenomenon, we propose a novel Hint-Practice Reasoning (HPR) framework that operationalizes this insight through two synergistic components: 1) a hinter (powerful LLM) that provides probabilistic guidance at critical decision points, and 2) a practitioner (efficient smaller model) that executes major reasoning steps. The framework's core innovation lies in Distributional Inconsistency Reduction (DIR), a theoretically-grounded metric that dynamically identifies intervention points by quantifying the divergence between practitioner's reasoning trajectory and hinter's expected distribution in a tree-structured probabilistic space. Through iterative tree updates guided by DIR, HPR reweights promising reasoning paths while deprioritizing low-probability branches. Experiments across arithmetic and commonsense reasoning benchmarks demonstrate HPR's state-of-the-art efficiency-accuracy tradeoffs: it achieves comparable performance to self-consistency and MCTS baselines while decoding only 1/5 tokens, and outperforms existing methods by at most 5.1% absolute accuracy while maintaining similar or lower FLOPs.

item.title: Radiology Workflow-Guided Hierarchical Reinforcement Fine-Tuning for Medical Report Generation
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Medical Report Generation, Reinforcement Learning, Radiology Reports, Hierarchical Modeling, Diagnostic Accuracy

Summary: This paper introduces RadFlow, a novel hierarchical workflow-guided reinforcement learning framework designed to improve medical report generation (MRG) by aligning with the structured nature of radiological reporting. Unlike traditional models that treat reports as flat sequences, RadFlow explicitly models the hierarchical organization found in clinical workflows, separating the descriptive "Findings" and diagnostic "Impressions" sections. The framework incorporates a clinically grounded reward hierarchy with global and local levels: the global reward balances linguistic fluency, medical correctness, and cross-sectional consistency between Findings and Impressions, ensuring coherent and accurate narratives, while the local reward emphasizes the quality of the Impression section, reflecting its importance for diagnostic accuracy. Additionally, RadFlow introduces a critical-aware policy optimization mechanism that adaptively regularizes model learning on high-risk or clinically sensitive cases, mimicking radiologists’ cautious refinement process for critical findings. Together, these components enable reinforcement fine-tuning that fosters generation of reports with improved coherence, clinical faithfulness, and linguistic quality. Experiments conducted on chest X-ray and carotid ultrasound datasets demonstrate that RadFlow consistently outperforms state-of-the-art baselines, leading to enhanced diagnostic consistency and overall report quality in generated medical reports.
arXiv:2511.10065v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Radiologists compose diagnostic reports through a structured workflow: they describe visual findings, summarize them into impressions, and carefully refine statements in clinically critical cases. However, most existing medical report generation (MRG) systems treat reports as flat sequences, overlooking this hierarchical organization and leading to inconsistencies between descriptive and diagnostic content. To align model behavior with real-world reporting practices, we propose RadFlow, a hierarchical workflow-guided reinforcement optimization framework that explicitly models the structured nature of clinical reporting. RadFlow introduces a clinically grounded reward hierarchy that mirrors the organization of radiological reports. At the global level, the reward integrates linguistic fluency, medical-domain correctness, and cross-sectional consistency between Finding and Impression, promoting coherent and clinically faithful narratives. At the local level, a section-specific reward emphasizes Impression quality, reflecting its central role in diagnostic accuracy. Furthermore, a critical-aware policy optimization mechanism adaptively regularizes learning for high-risk or clinically sensitive cases, emulating the cautious refinement behavior of radiologists when documenting critical findings. Together, these components translate the structured reporting paradigm into the reinforcement fine-tuning process, enabling the model to generate reports that are both linguistically consistent and clinically aligned. Experiments on chest X-ray and carotid ultrasound datasets demonstrate that RadFlow consistently improves diagnostic coherence and overall report quality compared with state-of-the-art baselines.

item.title: Enhancing the Medical Context-Awareness Ability of LLMs via Multifaceted Self-Refinement Learning
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Large language models, context-awareness, self-evaluation, medical domain, supervised fine-tuning

Summary:
Large language models (LLMs) have shown strong performance on medical benchmarks but still struggle in real-world medical scenarios due to insufficient context-awareness. To improve this, the authors propose Multifaceted Self-Refinement (MuSeR), a data-driven method that enhances LLMs' abilities in decision-making, communication, and safety through iterative self-evaluation and refinement. They design an attribute-conditioned query generator that simulates diverse real-world medical contexts by varying user roles, geographic regions, intents, and information ambiguity. The LLM responds to these queries, then self-assesses and refines its answers based on the three key facets mentioned. These refined responses, along with the queries, are used for supervised fine-tuning to reinforce context-awareness. Evaluations on the HealthBench dataset demonstrate significant improvements in LLM performance, especially on the context-awareness axis. Additionally, by applying knowledge distillation with MuSeR, a smaller LLM model (Qwen3-32B) outperforms its larger teacher model, setting a new state of the art among open-source LLMs on HealthBench, achieving 63.8% overall and 43.1% on the hard subset. The authors plan to release the code and dataset at https://muser-llm.github.io.
arXiv:2511.10067v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large language models (LLMs) have shown great promise in the medical domain, achieving strong performance on several benchmarks. However, they continue to underperform in real-world medical scenarios, which often demand stronger context-awareness, i.e., the ability to recognize missing or critical details (e.g., user identity, medical history, risk factors) and provide safe, helpful, and contextually appropriate responses. To address this issue, we propose Multifaceted Self-Refinement (MuSeR), a data-driven approach that enhances LLMs' context-awareness along three key facets (decision-making, communication, and safety) through self-evaluation and refinement. Specifically, we first design a attribute-conditioned query generator that simulates diverse real-world user contexts by varying attributes such as role, geographic region, intent, and degree of information ambiguity. An LLM then responds to these queries, self-evaluates its answers along three key facets, and refines its responses to better align with the requirements of each facet. Finally, the queries and refined responses are used for supervised fine-tuning to reinforce the model's context-awareness ability. Evaluation results on the latest HealthBench dataset demonstrate that our method significantly improves LLM performance across multiple aspects, with particularly notable gains in the context-awareness axis. Furthermore, by incorporating knowledge distillation with the proposed method, the performance of a smaller backbone LLM (e.g., Qwen3-32B) surpasses its teacher model, achieving a new SOTA across all open-source LLMs on HealthBench (63.8%) and its hard subset (43.1%). Code and dataset will be released at https://muser-llm.github.io.

item.title: Balancing Centralized Learning and Distributed Self-Organization: A Hybrid Model for Embodied Morphogenesis
item.content:encoded:
Learnable controller, Gray--Scott model, reaction--diffusion, morphological computation, energy-efficient control

Summary: This paper explores integrating a learnable "brain-like" neural controller with a "cell-like" Gray--Scott reaction--diffusion substrate to steer pattern formation efficiently. The approach embeds a compact convolutional policy within a differentiable PyTorch simulator, enabling smooth, bounded modulations of the Gray--Scott feed and kill parameters guided by a warm--hold--decay gain schedule. Training optimizes for Turing-band spectral pattern targets via FFT, while simultaneously penalizing control effort using combined \(\ell_1/\ell_2\) norms and discouraging instability. The study compares three regimes: pure reaction-diffusion, neural network (NN)-dominant control, and a hybrid coupling. The hybrid method achieves reliable and rapid formation of target textures with 100% strict convergence in approximately 165 steps, closely matching cell-only spectral selectivity (0.436 vs. 0.434), yet using significantly less control effort—around 15× less \(\ell_1\) and over 200× less \(\ell_2\) power than NN-dominant control. The analysis identifies a "Goldilocks" amplitude zone (around 0.03–0.045) that achieves 100% quasi convergence in 94–96 steps, while gains outside this range cause poor convergence or spectral degradation. The findings quantitatively demonstrate morphological computation, where the controller provides sparse initial nudges to guide the system into a stable pattern basin, after which the local reaction--diffusion dynamics maintain the pattern autonomously. This offers a practical framework for designing energy-efficient, robust embodied systems that optimally divide labor between centralized learning and distributed self-organization.
arXiv:2511.10101v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We investigate how to couple a learnable brain-like'' controller to a cell-like'' Gray--Scott substrate to steer pattern formation with minimal effort. A compact convolutional policy is embedded in a differentiable PyTorch reaction--diffusion simulator, producing spatially smooth, bounded modulations of the feed and kill parameters ($\Delta F$, $\Delta K$) under a warm--hold--decay gain schedule. Training optimizes Turing-band spectral targets (FFT-based) while penalizing control effort ($\ell_1/\ell_2$) and instability. We compare three regimes: pure reaction--diffusion, NN-dominant, and a hybrid coupling. The hybrid achieves reliable, fast formation of target textures: 100% strict convergence in $\sim 165$ steps, matching cell-only spectral selectivity (0.436 vs.\ 0.434) while using $\sim 15\times$ less $\ell_1$ effort and $>200\times$ less $\ell_2$ power than NN-dominant control. An amplitude sweep reveals a non-monotonic Goldilocks'' zone ($A \approx 0.03$--$0.045$) that yields 100\% quasi convergence in 94--96 steps, whereas weaker or stronger gains fail to converge or degrade selectivity. These results quantify morphological computation: the controller seeds then cedes,'' providing brief, sparse nudges that place the system in the correct basin of attraction, after which local physics maintains the pattern. The study offers a practical recipe for building steerable, robust, and energy-efficient embodied systems that exploit an optimal division of labor between centralized learning and distributed self-organization.

item.title: Intilligence Foundation Model: A New Perspective to Approach Artificial General Intelligence
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: artificial general intelligence, intelligence foundation model, state neural network, neuron output prediction, biological neural dynamics

Summary: This article proposes a novel approach to artificial general intelligence (AGI) through the development of an intelligence foundation model (IFM), which differs from traditional foundation models specialized in specific domains by learning from diverse intelligent behaviors. The core idea is that vision, language, and other cognitive abilities are manifestations of underlying intelligent behavior, and by learning from this broad behavioral spectrum, the system can internalize general principles of intelligence. The IFM is built on two key components: a new network architecture called the state neural network, designed to capture neuron-like temporal dynamics reflective of biological neural systems, and a new learning objective termed neuron output prediction, which trains the model to predict neuronal outputs from the collective neural dynamics. The state neural network enables the system to store, integrate, and process information over time in a manner akin to biological neurons. Meanwhile, the neuron output prediction serves as a unified computational principle to learn these dynamics based on observed intelligent behaviors. Together, these innovations provide a biologically inspired yet scalable foundation to create systems capable of generalization, reasoning, and adaptive learning across different domains, marking a significant step toward achieving true AGI.
arXiv:2511.10119v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We propose a new perspective for approaching artificial general intelligence (AGI) through an intelligence foundation model (IFM). Unlike existing foundation models (FMs), which specialize in pattern learning within specific domains such as language, vision, or time series, IFM aims to acquire the underlying mechanisms of intelligence by learning directly from diverse intelligent behaviors. Vision, language, and other cognitive abilities are manifestations of intelligent behavior; learning from this broad range of behaviors enables the system to internalize the general principles of intelligence. Based on the fact that intelligent behaviors emerge from the collective dynamics of biological neural systems, IFM consists of two core components: a novel network architecture, termed the state neural network, which captures neuron-like dynamic processes, and a new learning objective, neuron output prediction, which trains the system to predict neuronal outputs from collective dynamics. The state neural network emulates the temporal dynamics of biological neurons, allowing the system to store, integrate, and process information over time, while the neuron output prediction objective provides a unified computational principle for learning these structural dynamics from intelligent behaviors. Together, these innovations establish a biologically grounded and computationally scalable foundation for building systems capable of generalization, reasoning, and adaptive learning across domains, representing a step toward truly AGI.

item.title: RAGFort: Dual-Path Defense Against Proprietary Knowledge Base Extraction in Retrieval-Augmented Generation
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Retrieval-Augmented Generation, reconstruction attacks, knowledge base security, contrastive reindexing, constrained cascade generation

Summary:

1. The paper addresses the rising threat of reconstruction attacks on Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) systems that use proprietary knowledge bases, where attackers aggregate model responses to replicate sensitive knowledge.

2. These attacks exploit two main extraction paths: intra-class (within topic) and inter-class (across semantically related topics), progressively reconstructing detailed knowledge.

3. Existing defense mechanisms typically protect only one of these paths, leaving the other vulnerable to attack.

4. Through systematic evaluation, the authors demonstrate that protecting both intra-class and inter-class paths simultaneously is crucial for effective defense against knowledge base extraction.

5. To address this, they propose RAGFort, a dual-module approach combining contrastive reindexing to isolate inter-class information and constrained cascade generation to limit intra-class knowledge leakage.

6. Experimental results show that RAGFort significantly reduces the success rate of reconstruction attacks while maintaining high answer quality and overall system robustness.

7. The work contributes a comprehensive, structure-aware defense strategy that enhances security for RAG-based knowledge base deployments without compromising performance.
arXiv:2511.10128v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) systems deployed over proprietary knowledge bases face growing threats from reconstruction attacks that aggregate model responses to replicate knowledge bases. Such attacks exploit both intra-class and inter-class paths, progressively extracting fine-grained knowledge within topics and diffusing it across semantically related ones, thereby enabling comprehensive extraction of the original knowledge base. However, existing defenses target only one path, leaving the other unprotected. We conduct a systematic exploration to assess the impact of protecting each path independently and find that joint protection is essential for effective defense. Based on this, we propose RAGFort, a structure-aware dual-module defense combining "contrastive reindexing" for inter-class isolation and "constrained cascade generation" for intra-class protection. Experiments across security, performance, and robustness confirm that RAGFort significantly reduces reconstruction success while preserving answer quality, offering comprehensive defense against knowledge base extraction attacks.

item.title: DenoGrad: Deep Gradient Denoising Framework for Enhancing the Performance of Interpretable AI Models
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Denoising, Interpretable AI, Gradient-based correction, Data distribution preservation, Machine Learning robustness

Summary:

1. The paper addresses the significant impact of noise in both training and production data on the performance of Machine Learning models, especially those within the Interpretable Artificial Intelligence framework. 2. Denoising is a critical preprocessing step and is commonly divided into instance removal and instance correction methods, but existing correction techniques often harm model performance or distort the original data distribution. 3. The authors argue that defining noise independently from the target solution is ineffective because noise characteristics vary across tasks and datasets; thus, a task-specific high-quality solution should be used as the noise reference. 4. They propose DenoGrad, a novel Gradient-based instance Denoiser framework that exploits gradients from an accurate Deep Learning model trained on the target data to detect and correct noisy samples dynamically and adaptively. 5. Unlike traditional methods, DenoGrad preserves the original data distribution while improving the robustness of AI models, especially interpretable ones. The framework is validated on tabular and time series datasets under various noise conditions, outperforming state-of-the-art denoising strategies.
arXiv:2511.10161v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The performance of Machine Learning (ML) models, particularly those operating within the Interpretable Artificial Intelligence (Interpretable AI) framework, is significantly affected by the presence of noise in both training and production data. Denoising has therefore become a critical preprocessing step, typically categorized into instance removal and instance correction techniques. However, existing correction approaches often degrade performance or oversimplify the problem by altering the original data distribution. This leads to unrealistic scenarios and biased models, which is particularly problematic in contexts where interpretable AI models are employed, as their interpretability depends on the fidelity of the underlying data patterns. In this paper, we argue that defining noise independently of the solution may be ineffective, as its nature can vary significantly across tasks and datasets. Using a task-specific high quality solution as a reference can provide a more precise and adaptable noise definition. To this end, we propose DenoGrad, a novel Gradient-based instance Denoiser framework that leverages gradients from an accurate Deep Learning (DL) model trained on the target data -- regardless of the specific task -- to detect and adjust noisy samples. Unlike conventional approaches, DenoGrad dynamically corrects noisy instances, preserving problem's data distribution, and improving AI models robustness. DenoGrad is validated on both tabular and time series datasets under various noise settings against the state-of-the-art. DenoGrad outperforms existing denoising strategies, enhancing the performance of interpretable IA models while standing out as the only high quality approach that preserves the original data distribution.

item.title: Two Constraint Compilation Methods for Lifted Planning
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: PDDL planning, qualitative state-trajectory constraints, compilation without grounding, large-scale planning, planning competition evaluation

Summary: This paper addresses planning problems within a fragment of PDDL that includes qualitative state-trajectory constraints, which represent crucial real-world requirements such as safety, task ordering, and intermediate goals. Traditional approaches rely on compiling away these constraints to leverage existing state-of-the-art planners. However, these methods require grounding the problem first, which does not scale well for problems with many objects or high-arity actions. To overcome this limitation, the authors propose two novel compilation methods that do not require grounding, thus enabling scalability to large planning problems. They provide formal proofs of the correctness of these compilers and analyze their worst-case time complexity. An empirical evaluation using benchmark domains from the International Planning Competition demonstrates that their approaches generate planning specifications significantly more compact—by orders of magnitude—compared to grounding-based compilers. Furthermore, despite the increased succinctness, their compiled specifications remain competitive in planning performance when used with advanced planners. Overall, the work contributes scalable, formally backed compilation techniques that facilitate efficient planning in complex, constraint-rich domains without the bottleneck of grounding.
arXiv:2511.10164v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We study planning in a fragment of PDDL with qualitative state-trajectory constraints, capturing safety requirements, task ordering conditions, and intermediate sub-goals commonly found in real-world problems. A prominent approach to tackle such problems is to compile their constraints away, leading to a problem that is supported by state-of-the-art planners. Unfortunately, existing compilers do not scale on problems with a large number of objects and high-arity actions, as they necessitate grounding the problem before compilation. To address this issue, we propose two methods for compiling away constraints without grounding, making them suitable for large-scale planning problems. We prove the correctness of our compilers and outline their worst-case time complexity. Moreover, we present a reproducible empirical evaluation on the domains used in the latest International Planning Competition. Our results demonstrate that our methods are efficient and produce planning specifications that are orders of magnitude more succinct than the ones produced by compilers that ground the domain, while remaining competitive when used for planning with a state-of-the-art planner.

item.title: Advanced Black-Box Tuning of Large Language Models with Limited API Calls
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: black-box tuning, large language models, Gaussian Process surrogate, API call reduction, proxy model training

Summary:

This paper addresses the challenge of adapting large language models (LLMs) when direct access to model parameters is not possible, focusing on black-box tuning methods. Existing approaches either rely on training a small proxy model separately, which is efficient but offers limited improvements, or require frequent API calls to the foundation model, resulting in high computational costs. To overcome this dilemma, the authors propose an advanced black-box tuning approach that drastically reduces the number of API calls while maintaining or improving accuracy. The core innovation is the use of a Gaussian Process (GP) surrogate model trained on "LogitMap Pairs," which are obtained from minimal yet highly informative queries to the foundation model. This surrogate approximates the foundation model’s behavior, enabling proxy model training with fewer direct API queries. Experimental results demonstrate a significant accuracy improvement from 55.92% to 86.85%, while reducing API query frequency to just 1.38%. This method outperforms fully offline approaches with no API access and rivals query-intensive methods in accuracy, offering a cost-effective and efficient paradigm for language model adaptation in black-box scenarios.
arXiv:2511.10210v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Black-box tuning is an emerging paradigm for adapting large language models (LLMs) to better achieve desired behaviors, particularly when direct access to model parameters is unavailable. Current strategies, however, often present a dilemma of suboptimal extremes: either separately train a small proxy model and then use it to shift the predictions of the foundation model, offering notable efficiency but often yielding limited improvement; or making API calls in each tuning iteration to the foundation model, which entails prohibitive computational costs. Therefore, we propose a novel advanced black-box tuning method for LLMs with limited API calls. Our core strategy involves training a Gaussian Process (GP) surrogate model with "LogitMap Pairs" derived from querying the foundation model on a minimal but highly informative training subset. This surrogate can approximate the outputs of the foundation model to guide the training of the proxy model, thereby effectively reducing the need for direct queries to the foundation model. Extensive experiments verify that our approach elevates pre-trained language model accuracy from 55.92% to 86.85%, reducing the frequency of API queries to merely 1.38%. This significantly outperforms offline approaches that operate entirely without API access. Notably, our method also achieves comparable or superior accuracy to query-intensive approaches, while significantly reducing API costs. This offers a robust and high-efficiency paradigm for language model adaptation.

item.title: MTP: Exploring Multimodal Urban Traffic Profiling with Modality Augmentation and Spectrum Fusion
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: multimodal learning, traffic signal modeling, frequency domain, contrastive learning, urban mobility

Summary:
1. The paper addresses challenges in modeling urban traffic signals, highlighting limitations of existing unimodal approaches that rely solely on numerical sensor data and neglect semantic information from heterogeneous urban data.
2. To overcome this, the authors propose MTP (Multimodal Traffic Profiling), a novel multimodal framework integrating numeric, visual, and textual data sources to capture comprehensive traffic signal features.
3. The framework conducts visual augmentation by converting traffic signals into frequency and periodicity images for enhanced visual feature extraction.
4. Textual augmentation is performed using descriptive texts enriched with topic, background, and item-specific information for improved textual representation.
5. Numeric data is processed through frequency multilayer perceptrons to extract refined frequency-domain features.
6. A hierarchical contrastive learning approach is designed to effectively fuse multimodal information across the three data branches.
7. Experimental validation on six real-world datasets demonstrates that MTP significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in modeling and predicting complex traffic dynamics, supporting safer travel and optimized urban mobility.
arXiv:2511.10218v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: With rapid urbanization in the modern era, traffic signals from various sensors have been playing a significant role in monitoring the states of cities, which provides a strong foundation in ensuring safe travel, reducing traffic congestion and optimizing urban mobility. Most existing methods for traffic signal modeling often rely on the original data modality, i.e., numerical direct readings from the sensors in cities. However, this unimodal approach overlooks the semantic information existing in multimodal heterogeneous urban data in different perspectives, which hinders a comprehensive understanding of traffic signals and limits the accurate prediction of complex traffic dynamics. To address this problem, we propose a novel \textit{M}ultimodal framework, \textit{MTP}, for urban \textit{T}raffic \textit{P}rofiling, which learns multimodal features through numeric, visual, and textual perspectives. The three branches drive for a multimodal perspective of urban traffic signal learning in the frequency domain, while the frequency learning strategies delicately refine the information for extraction. Specifically, we first conduct the visual augmentation for the traffic signals, which transforms the original modality into frequency images and periodicity images for visual learning. Also, we augment descriptive texts for the traffic signals based on the specific topic, background information and item description for textual learning. To complement the numeric information, we utilize frequency multilayer perceptrons for learning on the original modality. We design a hierarchical contrastive learning on the three branches to fuse the spectrum of three modalities. Finally, extensive experiments on six real-world datasets demonstrate superior performance compared with the state-of-the-art approaches.

item.title: Bridging Synthetic and Real Routing Problems via LLM-Guided Instance Generation and Progressive Adaptation
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Neural Combinatorial Optimization, Vehicle Routing Problem, Instance Synthesis, Large Language Models, Generalization

Summary: Recent developments in Neural Combinatorial Optimization (NCO) have enhanced neural solvers' performance on synthetic routing problems but face challenges generalizing to real-world Vehicle Routing Problem (VRP) instances. This paper introduces Evolutionary Realistic Instance Synthesis (EvoReal), an approach that leverages an evolutionary module guided by large language models (LLMs) to generate synthetic VRP instances with structural characteristics resembling real-world benchmarks. EvoReal works by creating synthetic instances whose structural attributes statistically mirror those of authentic real data, thereby enriching the training distribution. NCO models are then progressively refined: first by aligning them with this newly synthesized, structurally realistic data, and subsequently via direct fine-tuning on established benchmark datasets including TSPLib and CVRPLib. Through extensive experiments, EvoReal significantly improves the generalization ability of leading neural solvers, reducing the performance gap relative to optimal solutions to 1.05% on TSPLib and 2.71% on CVRPLib. This approach effectively bridges the gap between training on synthetic uniform data and testing on real-world VRP instances across diverse problem scales, marking a substantial step forward in applying NCO methods to practical routing problems.
arXiv:2511.10233v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Recent advances in Neural Combinatorial Optimization (NCO) methods have significantly improved the capability of neural solvers to handle synthetic routing instances. Nonetheless, existing neural solvers typically struggle to generalize effectively from synthetic, uniformly-distributed training data to real-world VRP scenarios, including widely recognized benchmark instances from TSPLib and CVRPLib. To bridge this generalization gap, we present Evolutionary Realistic Instance Synthesis (EvoReal), which leverages an evolutionary module guided by large language models (LLMs) to generate synthetic instances characterized by diverse and realistic structural patterns. Specifically, the evolutionary module produces synthetic instances whose structural attributes statistically mimics those observed in authentic real-world instances. Subsequently, pre-trained NCO models are progressively refined, firstly aligning them with these structurally enriched synthetic distributions and then further adapting them through direct fine-tuning on actual benchmark instances. Extensive experimental evaluations demonstrate that EvoReal markedly improves the generalization capabilities of state-of-the-art neural solvers, yielding a notable reduced performance gap compared to the optimal solutions on the TSPLib (1.05%) and CVRPLib (2.71%) benchmarks across a broad spectrum of problem scales.

item.title: ProgRAG: Hallucination-Resistant Progressive Retrieval and Reasoning over Knowledge Graphs
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Large Language Models, knowledge graphs, multi-hop question answering, uncertainty-aware pruning, reasoning paths

Summary:

This paper addresses the limitations of Large Language Models (LLMs) in reasoning, particularly hallucinations and transparency issues, by integrating knowledge graphs (KGs) to enhance performance on complex knowledge-intensive tasks. Existing KG-enhanced LLM methods suffer from inaccurate retrieval, reasoning failures, and challenges caused by long input contexts and inadequate context constructions for different question types. To overcome these challenges, the authors propose ProgRAG, a multi-hop knowledge graph question answering (KGQA) framework that decomposes complex questions into manageable sub-questions. ProgRAG progressively extends partial reasoning paths by sequentially answering these sub-questions, thereby structuring the reasoning process. At each step, external retrievers collect candidate evidence, which is then refined using uncertainty-aware pruning powered by the LLM, reducing noise and improving relevance. The final reasoning context for the LLM is optimized by organizing and rearranging the partial reasoning paths derived from answers to sub-questions, enhancing logical clarity and reasoning quality. Experimental results across three benchmark datasets demonstrate that ProgRAG outperforms current approaches in multi-hop KGQA tasks, offering improved reliability, accuracy, and reasoning quality in complex question answering scenarios.
arXiv:2511.10240v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) demonstrate strong reasoning capabilities but struggle with hallucinations and limited transparency. Recently, KG-enhanced LLMs that integrate knowledge graphs (KGs) have been shown to improve reasoning performance, particularly for complex, knowledge-intensive tasks. However, these methods still face significant challenges, including inaccurate retrieval and reasoning failures, often exacerbated by long input contexts that obscure relevant information or by context constructions that struggle to capture the richer logical directions required by different question types. Furthermore, many of these approaches rely on LLMs to directly retrieve evidence from KGs, and to self-assess the sufficiency of this evidence, which often results in premature or incorrect reasoning. To address the retrieval and reasoning failures, we propose ProgRAG, a multi-hop knowledge graph question answering (KGQA) framework that decomposes complex questions into sub-questions, and progressively extends partial reasoning paths by answering each sub-question. At each step, external retrievers gather candidate evidence, which is then refined through uncertainty-aware pruning by the LLM. Finally, the context for LLM reasoning is optimized by organizing and rearranging the partial reasoning paths obtained from the sub-question answers. Experiments on three well-known datasets demonstrate that ProgRAG outperforms existing baselines in multi-hop KGQA, offering improved reliability and reasoning quality.

item.title: PepTriX: A Framework for Explainable Peptide Analysis through Protein Language Models
item.content:encoded:
Peptide classification, protein language models, graph attention network, contrastive training, interpretability

Summary: This paper presents PepTriX, a novel framework designed for peptide classification tasks such as toxicity prediction and HIV inhibition, which are critical in bioinformatics and drug discovery. Traditional methods rely on handcrafted 1D peptide sequence encodings, limiting generalization across datasets and tasks. While recent protein language models like ESM-2 and ESMFold deliver strong performance, they suffer from costly fine-tuning and complex latent representations that reduce interpretability for domain experts. PepTriX addresses these challenges by integrating 1D sequence embeddings with 3D structural features using a graph attention network enhanced by contrastive training and cross-modal co-attention mechanisms. This approach allows automatic adaptation to diverse datasets, generating task-specific peptide vectors that maintain biological relevance. Evaluation by domain experts reveals that PepTriX not only achieves robust, accurate predictions across multiple peptide classification tasks but also offers interpretable insights into the structural and biophysical motifs influencing the results. Consequently, PepTriX bridges the gap between high-performance peptide-level models and biologically meaningful, interpretable representations, fostering improved understanding and validation in peptide research.
arXiv:2511.10244v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Peptide classification tasks, such as predicting toxicity and HIV inhibition, are fundamental to bioinformatics and drug discovery. Traditional approaches rely heavily on handcrafted encodings of one-dimensional (1D) peptide sequences, which can limit generalizability across tasks and datasets. Recently, protein language models (PLMs), such as ESM-2 and ESMFold, have demonstrated strong predictive performance. However, they face two critical challenges. First, fine-tuning is computationally costly. Second, their complex latent representations hinder interpretability for domain experts. Additionally, many frameworks have been developed for specific types of peptide classification, lacking generalization. These limitations restrict the ability to connect model predictions to biologically relevant motifs and structural properties. To address these limitations, we present PepTriX, a novel framework that integrates one dimensional (1D) sequence embeddings and three-dimensional (3D) structural features via a graph attention network enhanced with contrastive training and cross-modal co-attention. PepTriX automatically adapts to diverse datasets, producing task-specific peptide vectors while retaining biological plausibility. After evaluation by domain experts, we found that PepTriX performs remarkably well across multiple peptide classification tasks and provides interpretable insights into the structural and biophysical motifs that drive predictions. Thus, PepTriX offers both predictive robustness and interpretable validation, bridging the gap between performance-driven peptide-level models (PLMs) and domain-level understanding in peptide research.

item.title: Beyond Single-Step Updates: Reinforcement Learning of Heuristics with Limited-Horizon Search
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: heuristic search, sequential decision-making, reinforcement learning, approximate value iteration, shortest-path problem

Summary: Many sequential decision-making problems can be formulated as shortest-path problems, where the goal is to find the minimum cost path from a start state to a goal state. Heuristic search methods are commonly used in solving these problems by estimating the cost to reach the goal from any given state through a heuristic function. Recent advances use reinforcement learning techniques, specifically deep approximate value iteration, to learn these heuristics automatically. Traditional methods typically perform single-step Bellman updates, updating the heuristic value of a state based only on its best immediate neighbor and edge cost. This paper proposes a generalized framework that improves both the sampling of states and the update of heuristics by conducting limited-horizon searches. Instead of only considering immediate neighbors, the heuristic of each state is updated based on the shortest path cost to the search frontier, which integrates both edge costs along the path and heuristic values of the frontier states. This approach potentially leads to more informed heuristic updates, improving the quality and efficiency of heuristic search in sequential decision-making tasks.
arXiv:2511.10264v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Many sequential decision-making problems can be formulated as shortest-path problems, where the objective is to reach a goal state from a given starting state. Heuristic search is a standard approach for solving such problems, relying on a heuristic function to estimate the cost to the goal from any given state. Recent approaches leverage reinforcement learning to learn heuristics by applying deep approximate value iteration. These methods typically rely on single-step Bellman updates, where the heuristic of a state is updated based on its best neighbor and the corresponding edge cost. This work proposes a generalized approach that enhances both state sampling and heuristic updates by performing limited-horizon searches and updating each state's heuristic based on the shortest path to the search frontier, incorporating both edge costs and the heuristic values of frontier states.

item.title: Temporal Properties of Conditional Independence in Dynamic Bayesian Networks
item.content:encoded:
Dynamic Bayesian networks, Conditional independence, Temporal logic, Verification complexity, Structural properties

Summary:

Dynamic Bayesian networks (DBNs) model probabilistic systems with evolving interdependent random variables. This paper focuses on verifying the evolution of conditional-independence (CI) propositions within DBNs using temporal logic specifications. Two specification formalisms are considered: linear temporal logic (LTL) and non-deterministic Büchi automata (NBAs). Verification has two variants: stochastic CI properties, which account for specific probability distributions, and structural CI properties, which depend purely on the graphical structure of the DBN. The authors prove that deciding if a stochastic CI property eventually holds is at least as difficult as the Skolem problem, a well-known open problem in number theory. For structural CI properties, verification against LTL and NBA specifications lies within PSPACE complexity, but is NP- and coNP-hard. Additionally, the paper identifies certain natural restrictions on DBN graphical structures that make the verification of structural CI properties computationally feasible. Overall, this work advances understanding of the computational boundaries involved in verifying probabilistic independence relations evolving over time in DBNs.
arXiv:2511.10266v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Dynamic Bayesian networks (DBNs) are compact graphical representations used to model probabilistic systems where interdependent random variables and their distributions evolve over time. In this paper, we study the verification of the evolution of conditional-independence (CI) propositions against temporal logic specifications. To this end, we consider two specification formalisms over CI propositions: linear temporal logic (LTL), and non-deterministic B\"uchi automata (NBAs). This problem has two variants. Stochastic CI properties take the given concrete probability distributions into account, while structural CI properties are viewed purely in terms of the graphical structure of the DBN. We show that deciding if a stochastic CI proposition eventually holds is at least as hard as the Skolem problem for linear recurrence sequences, a long-standing open problem in number theory. On the other hand, we show that verifying the evolution of structural CI propositions against LTL and NBA specifications is in PSPACE, and is NP- and coNP-hard. We also identify natural restrictions on the graphical structure of DBNs that make the verification of structural CI properties tractable.

item.title: Causal-HalBench: Uncovering LVLMs Object Hallucinations Through Causal Intervention
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Large Vision-Language Models, object hallucination, spurious correlations, Structural Causal Model, Causal-HalBench

Summary: This paper addresses the problem of object hallucination in Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs), where models mistakenly detect objects in images that are not present. 1. The root cause is identified as spurious correlations, especially due to frequent co-occurrences of certain objects during training, causing models to be biased by visual context rather than actual content. 2. Existing benchmarks focus mainly on detecting hallucinations but do not formally characterize or quantitatively evaluate the role of spurious correlations in LVLMs. 3. To fill this gap, the authors introduce a causal analysis framework by developing a Structural Causal Model (SCM) tailored to the object recognition scenario in LVLMs, which allows formal definition of spurious correlations via causality concepts. 4. They propose Causal-HalBench, a new benchmark containing counterfactual samples alongside comprehensive causal metrics, designed to rigorously measure the robustness of LVLMs against spurious co-occurrence bias. 5. Additionally, an extensible pipeline for generating these counterfactual samples is introduced, exploiting proprietary LVLMs and Text-to-Image (T2I) models to create realistic and controlled data variations. 6. Experimental results on popular LVLMs using the Causal-HalBench demonstrate that while all tested models are vulnerable to spurious correlations, the extent of their susceptibility varies, highlighting a need for improved model design and evaluation.
arXiv:2511.10268v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs) often suffer from object hallucination, making erroneous judgments about the presence of objects in images. We propose this primar- ily stems from spurious correlations arising when models strongly associate highly co-occurring objects during train- ing, leading to hallucinated objects influenced by visual con- text. Current benchmarks mainly focus on hallucination de- tection but lack a formal characterization and quantitative evaluation of spurious correlations in LVLMs. To address this, we introduce causal analysis into the object recognition scenario of LVLMs, establishing a Structural Causal Model (SCM). Utilizing the language of causality, we formally de- fine spurious correlations arising from co-occurrence bias. To quantify the influence induced by these spurious correla- tions, we develop Causal-HalBench, a benchmark specifically constructed with counterfactual samples and integrated with comprehensive causal metrics designed to assess model ro- bustness against spurious correlations. Concurrently, we pro- pose an extensible pipeline for the construction of these coun- terfactual samples, leveraging the capabilities of proprietary LVLMs and Text-to-Image (T2I) models for their genera- tion. Our evaluations on mainstream LVLMs using Causal- HalBench demonstrate these models exhibit susceptibility to spurious correlations, albeit to varying extents.

item.title: Bidirectional Bounded-Suboptimal Heuristic Search with Consistent Heuristics
item.content:encoded:
bidirectional search, bounded-suboptimal, BAE*, weighted A*, heuristic algorithms

Summary:

This paper addresses the area of bounded-suboptimal bidirectional heuristic search, which involves finding solutions within a predefined bound on solution cost suboptimality. Unlike previous research focusing primarily on optimal bidirectional search algorithms, the authors extend the state-of-the-art optimal bidirectional search algorithm BAE*, originally designed for consistent heuristics, by developing several variants tailored specifically for bounded-suboptimal search. These new variants aim to balance solution quality with computational efficiency under specified suboptimality bounds. The study includes an experimental evaluation comparing the performance of the proposed BAE* variants against other existing bounded-suboptimal bidirectional search algorithms as well as the well-known weighted A* algorithm. Results indicate that no single algorithm dominates universally; instead, each method shows superior performance in different problem settings or under varying conditions. This highlights the nuanced trade-offs between search efficiency, optimality bounds, and heuristic consistency in bounded-suboptimal bidirectional search. The work contributes to both theoretical understanding and practical considerations for designing heuristic search algorithms when approximate solutions within guaranteed bounds are acceptable.
arXiv:2511.10272v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Recent advancements in bidirectional heuristic search have yielded significant theoretical insights and novel algorithms. While most previous work has concentrated on optimal search methods, this paper focuses on bounded-suboptimal bidirectional search, where a bound on the suboptimality of the solution cost is specified. We build upon the state-of-the-art optimal bidirectional search algorithm, BAE*, designed for consistent heuristics, and introduce several variants of BAE* specifically tailored for the bounded-suboptimal context. Through experimental evaluation, we compare the performance of these new variants against other bounded-suboptimal bidirectional algorithms as well as the standard weighted A* algorithm. Our results demonstrate that each algorithm excels under distinct conditions, highlighting the strengths and weaknesses of each approach.

item.title: Fixed-Persona SLMs with Modular Memory: Scalable NPC Dialogue on Consumer Hardware
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Small Language Models, NPC dialogue system, modular memory, persona-aligned training, gaming applications

Summary: This paper addresses the challenges of using Large Language Models (LLMs) in computer game dialogue systems due to their high hardware demands, latency issues, and difficulties in maintaining clear knowledge boundaries within game environments. To overcome these obstacles, the authors propose a modular NPC dialogue system that utilizes Small Language Models (SLMs). These SLMs are fine-tuned on synthetic, persona-aligned data to reflect specific NPC characters, ensuring personalized conversational behavior. The system integrates runtime-swappable memory modules that store character-specific conversational context and world knowledge. This design allows the NPCs to maintain expressive, consistent interactions and long-term memory capabilities during gameplay without needing to retrain models or reload them. The authors evaluate their approach using three open-source SLMs—DistilGPT-2, TinyLlama-1.1B-Chat, and Mistral-7B-Instruct—running on consumer-grade hardware, demonstrating its practicality and efficiency. Although the primary motivation is gaming, the modular design and persona-driven memory architecture make the system adaptable for broader domains such as virtual assistants, customer support bots, and interactive educational systems, where scalable, memory-rich, and expressive conversational agents are valuable.
arXiv:2511.10277v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities in generating human-like text, yet their applicability to dialogue systems in computer games remains limited. This limitation arises from their substantial hardware requirements, latency constraints, and the necessity to maintain clearly defined knowledge boundaries within a game setting. In this paper, we propose a modular NPC dialogue system that leverages Small Language Models (SLMs), fine-tuned to encode specific NPC personas and integrated with runtime-swappable memory modules. These memory modules preserve character-specific conversational context and world knowledge, enabling expressive interactions and long-term memory without retraining or model reloading during gameplay. We comprehensively evaluate our system using three open-source SLMs: DistilGPT-2, TinyLlama-1.1B-Chat, and Mistral-7B-Instruct, trained on synthetic persona-aligned data and benchmarked on consumer-grade hardware. While our approach is motivated by applications in gaming, its modular design and persona-driven memory architecture hold significant potential for broader adoption in domains requiring expressive, scalable, and memory-rich conversational agents, such as virtual assistants, customer support bots, or interactive educational systems.

item.title: FactGuard: Event-Centric and Commonsense-Guided Fake News Detection
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Fake news detection, large language models, writing style, event-centric content, knowledge distillation

Summary: This paper addresses the challenge of fake news detection, which has become less effective as adversaries mimic authentic news writing styles. To overcome this, the authors propose FactGuard, a novel framework that leverages large language models (LLMs) to extract event-centric content, minimizing dependence on writing style. FactGuard introduces a dynamic usability mechanism that detects contradictions and ambiguous factual reasoning, adaptively integrating LLM advice to improve the reliability of fake news identification. Recognizing the practical constraints of deploying LLMs, the authors also employ knowledge distillation to create FactGuard-D, a lightweight version designed for cold-start and resource-limited environments. Extensive experiments on two benchmark datasets demonstrate that FactGuard consistently outperforms existing methods, offering enhanced robustness and accuracy. The framework effectively addresses challenges related to style sensitivity and LLM usability, paving the way for more reliable and efficient fake news detection in real-world applications.
arXiv:2511.10281v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Fake news detection methods based on writing style have achieved remarkable progress. However, as adversaries increasingly imitate the style of authentic news, the effectiveness of such approaches is gradually diminishing. Recent research has explored incorporating large language models (LLMs) to enhance fake news detection. Yet, despite their transformative potential, LLMs remain an untapped goldmine for fake news detection, with their real-world adoption hampered by shallow functionality exploration, ambiguous usability, and prohibitive inference costs. In this paper, we propose a novel fake news detection framework, dubbed FactGuard, that leverages LLMs to extract event-centric content, thereby reducing the impact of writing style on detection performance. Furthermore, our approach introduces a dynamic usability mechanism that identifies contradictions and ambiguous cases in factual reasoning, adaptively incorporating LLM advice to improve decision reliability. To ensure efficiency and practical deployment, we employ knowledge distillation to derive FactGuard-D, enabling the framework to operate effectively in cold-start and resource-constrained scenarios. Comprehensive experiments on two benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach consistently outperforms existing methods in both robustness and accuracy, effectively addressing the challenges of style sensitivity and LLM usability in fake news detection.

item.title: Beyond Verification: Abductive Explanations for Post-AI Assessment of Privacy Leakage
item.content:encoded:
Privacy leakage, abductive explanations, AI decision-making, Potentially Applicable Explanations, privacy auditing

Summary:

This paper addresses privacy leakage risks inherent in AI-based decision-making systems, particularly when sensitive information can be inferred from model outputs. It introduces a formal framework for auditing privacy leakage by employing abductive explanations, which identify the minimal sufficient evidence justifying specific model decisions. The framework extends to both individual and system-level privacy leakage analyses and introduces the novel concept of Potentially Applicable Explanations (PAE) to recognize individuals whose decision outcomes can protect or “shield” those possessing sensitive features. Through this approach, the framework offers rigorous privacy guarantees while simultaneously providing human-understandable explanations crucial for auditing purposes. The authors validate their method experimentally using the German Credit Dataset, demonstrating how the involvement and importance of sensitive literals in the decision process impact privacy leakage. Despite facing computational challenges and relying on some simplifying assumptions, the results indicate that abductive reasoning is a viable tool for interpretable privacy auditing. Ultimately, the proposed framework highlights a practical avenue to balance transparency, model interpretability, and privacy preservation in AI decision-making systems.
arXiv:2511.10284v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Privacy leakage in AI-based decision processes poses significant risks, particularly when sensitive information can be inferred. We propose a formal framework to audit privacy leakage using abductive explanations, which identifies minimal sufficient evidence justifying model decisions and determines whether sensitive information disclosed. Our framework formalizes both individual and system-level leakage, introducing the notion of Potentially Applicable Explanations (PAE) to identify individuals whose outcomes can shield those with sensitive features. This approach provides rigorous privacy guarantees while producing human understandable explanations, a key requirement for auditing tools. Experimental evaluation on the German Credit Dataset illustrates how the importance of sensitive literal in the model decision process affects privacy leakage. Despite computational challenges and simplifying assumptions, our results demonstrate that abductive reasoning enables interpretable privacy auditing, offering a practical pathway to reconcile transparency, model interpretability, and privacy preserving in AI decision-making.

item.title: Massively Parallel Proof-Number Search for Impartial Games and Beyond
item.content:encoded:
Proof-Number Search, parallelization, Sprouts game, Grundy numbers, game solving

Summary:

1. The article presents a massively parallel version of the Proof-Number Search algorithm, which is a best-first search method used extensively in game solving.

2. Traditional parallel implementations of Proof-Number Search do not scale well across many CPU cores, limiting their effectiveness on large computing clusters.

3. By leveraging two levels of parallelization and enabling workers to share information, the authors achieve efficient scaling on up to 1024 CPU cores.

4. The solver is enhanced with Grundy numbers, a technique used to reduce the complexity of game trees, specifically applied to the Sprouts game, motivated by the Sprouts Conjecture.

5. The new solver achieves a 332.9× speedup on 1024 cores compared to previous versions, outperforms the state-of-the-art Sprouts solver GLOP by four orders of magnitude in runtime, and can handle proofs 1,000 times more complex.

6. Despite the exponential growth of the game tree size, the solver successfully verifies the Sprouts Conjecture for 42 new positions, nearly doubling the known outcomes and advancing the understanding of the game significantly.
arXiv:2511.10339v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Proof-Number Search is a best-first search algorithm with many successful applications, especially in game solving. As large-scale computing clusters become increasingly accessible, parallelization is a natural way to accelerate computation. However, existing parallel versions of Proof-Number Search are known to scale poorly on many CPU cores. Using two parallelized levels and shared information among workers, we present the first massively parallel version of Proof-Number Search that scales efficiently even on a large number of CPUs. We apply our solver, enhanced with Grundy numbers for reducing game trees, to the Sprouts game, a case study motivated by the long-standing Sprouts Conjecture. Our solver achieves a significantly improved 332.9$\times$ speedup when run on 1024 cores, enabling it to outperform the state-of-the-art Sprouts solver GLOP by four orders of magnitude in runtime and to generate proofs 1,000$\times$ more complex. Despite exponential growth in game tree size, our solver verified the Sprouts Conjecture for 42 new positions, nearly doubling the number of known outcomes.

item.title: SITA: A Framework for Structure-to-Instance Theorem Autoformalization
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: large language models, theorem autoformalization, abstract structures, Lean proof assistant, structure-to-instance theorem autoformalization (SITA)

Summary: This paper addresses the challenge of formalizing mathematical theorems that instantiate abstract structures within concrete settings, particularly focusing on research-level mathematics. The authors propose a novel framework called structure-to-instance theorem autoformalization (SITA), designed to bridge the gap between abstract theories and their concrete formalizations in the Lean proof assistant. In SITA, abstract mathematical structures are modular templates encapsulating definitions, assumptions, operations, and theorems, which can be reused as guides for formalizing specific instances. Given a concrete instantiation, the framework automatically generates corresponding Lean definitions and instance declarations, integrates them using Lean's typeclass mechanism, and verifies theorems by checking structural assumptions. The methodology combines large language model (LLM)-based generation with feedback-guided refinement to balance automation with formal correctness. Experimental evaluations on a dataset of optimization problems demonstrate SITA’s effectiveness in formalizing a variety of instances grounded in abstract frameworks. This work contributes to automated formal verification by enabling scalable, reusable, and verified formalizations of complex mathematical results across abstract and concrete domains.
arXiv:2511.10356v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: While large language models (LLMs) have shown progress in mathematical reasoning, they still face challenges in formalizing theorems that arise from instantiating abstract structures in concrete settings. With the goal of auto-formalizing mathematical results at the research level, we develop a framework for structure-to-instance theorem autoformalization (SITA), which systematically bridges the gap between abstract mathematical theories and their concrete applications in Lean proof assistant. Formalized abstract structures are treated as modular templates that contain definitions, assumptions, operations, and theorems. These templates serve as reusable guides for the formalization of concrete instances. Given a specific instantiation, we generate corresponding Lean definitions and instance declarations, integrate them using Lean's typeclass mechanism, and construct verified theorems by checking structural assumptions. We incorporate LLM-based generation with feedback-guided refinement to ensure both automation and formal correctness. Experiments on a dataset of optimization problems demonstrate that SITA effectively formalizes diverse instances grounded in abstract structures.

item.title: Explaining Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning Policies
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning, decentralized MARL, policy summarization, query-based explanations, user studies

Summary: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (MARL) has recently attracted widespread attention for enabling sequential decision-making across multiple agents in diverse application areas. However, existing explanation approaches mainly target centralized MARL and do not sufficiently address uncertainty and nondeterministic behaviors in decentralized MARL settings. This paper introduces novel methods for generating policy summarizations that accurately capture task sequencing and cooperation among agents operating under decentralized policies. Additionally, it presents query-based explanation techniques designed to answer specific user questions categorized as When, Why Not, and What, focusing on particular agent behaviors. The proposed approach is evaluated across four distinct MARL domains and two decentralized MARL algorithms, demonstrating its broad applicability and computational efficiency. User studies validate that these summarizations and explanations substantially improve users’ ability to answer questions about agent behavior and significantly enhance subjective measures such as understanding, clarity, and user satisfaction. The results emphasize the importance and effectiveness of tailored explanation methods in decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning contexts, facilitating better human interpretability and trust in complex agent systems.
arXiv:2511.10409v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (MARL) has gained significant interest in recent years, enabling sequential decision-making across multiple agents in various domains. However, most existing explanation methods focus on centralized MARL, failing to address the uncertainty and nondeterminism inherent in decentralized settings. We propose methods to generate policy summarizations that capture task ordering and agent cooperation in decentralized MARL policies, along with query-based explanations for When, Why Not, and What types of user queries about specific agent behaviors. We evaluate our approach across four MARL domains and two decentralized MARL algorithms, demonstrating its generalizability and computational efficiency.
